142430726.review:
Child of Light causes me immense heartbreak because of how much is missing from it - but I wouldn't feel this way if the backbone of it wasn't a heart-jerking wonderwork as it is.

The gameplay is recognizably comparable to those classic turn-based RPG's I've seen (I still ought to give one of those a shot someday. Any suggestions?) While adding a new twist of its own in the form of the timeline, skills and abilities that affect the timeline and others' place on it, and Igniculus's ability to interact with allies and adversaries.

The world's art; how can I do justice to it? To any of it? Almost every individual asset looks beautiful, with even the simplest drawn leaves looking like they're made with love.

Each of these assets together, make convincing animation that captures eye and mind - and against the ineffable backdrops? The world of Lumeria, nearly ever corner, looks real - not in the photorealistic sense, mind you, but in the sense of being signature and thorough, to the degree the boundary between Lumeria and belief melts, and we could reach in through our monitors and touch the world if that absurd screen wasn't in the way; the jaded degradation of broken-hearted adulthood gone, minimal disbelief left to suspend.

The effects and changes consist of elegant paint splatters and shifting lights, combined with the hand-drawn nature of the adversaries and most of our potential allies, really seem like a children's book that never existed, of a quality that our timeline has yet to receive for any children's picture book so far, is coming to life.

____

There are flaws. The denizens of Lumeria receive different facial expressions only in the talking hud; otherwise, they make no major facial expression variations, and this can be seen when exploring the overworld, when denizens leave your party and stand to await the completion of some puzzle, and during combat. Aurora and her cohorts do not wince, grin, look sad, or smile victoriously. 

Additionally, the tweening on most animations is tailored very much to look like paper itself, literally attempting to come to life, with most of the limitations you'd expect. Along with the aforementioned lack of facial expressions, it's great for selling the prospect of paper coming to life, but contrasts with the vibrant and living world.

___

My biggest complaint is the story-gameplay interaction features that had to be cut, particularly ones that work well for *role-playing*, in a *role-playing* game. I wanted a chance to role-play as an Aurora who refuses alliance with anyone but Igniculus and goes it alone, except for him. However, there are key story events that Aurora misses when trying this, which later words reference anyway, breaking immersion. Additionally, even if one weathers this storm, determined to make a nigh-independent Aurora, the requirement of bringing a character along becoming inevitable at no less than two points in the game. So not only are we forced to take along allies if we want the full story context, but the challenge is impossible anyway.

What's more, one of those inevitable allies is in my opinion one of the most likable in the game - [spoiler] until this ally suddenly betrays you and is someone completely different. There is build up to this but not enough to justify it. There is no way to redeem this one - a foul denial, given how likable this one had been made. The heartbreak is achieved alright, but it is a cheap shot that feels narratively unfair.[/spoiler]

Lastly, the ending is the same no matter what else you do. In a game whose coming-of-age themes include Aurora deciding who she trusts and what her priorities are, it is a railroad spike to the heart that we cannot make different choices and behold different ultimate results. This even includes playing the game on higher difficulty.

I am nearly fully convinced that these shortcomings are no evil of the developers themselves, but of bean counters who insisted on rushing art.
___

For all the dire that has befallen Child of Light, it is a beautiful gem - rough, and in need of more tumbling, like those used in-game as accessories to change one's stats. It has won from me a bittersweet and heartbroken love - and if you, reader, are uncowed, intrigued, the both, or elsewise entirely, I encourage you to purchase the game - when your fear of the expense is less than the call of Lemuria's Light.

Child of Light es un juego que prometía mucho, pero finalmente se vio decepcionado por una serie de problemas técnicos, en particular fallas y problemas de compatibilidad con algunas de las versiones más nuevas de Windows.

Uno de los mayores problemas de Child of Light es que se bloquea constantemente, lo que hace que pierdas el progreso de la partida. Estos bloqueos suelen ocurrir durante las cinemáticas o cuando ingresas a nuevas áreas, y pueden ser difíciles de predecir o evitar. Esto hace que sea difícil disfrutar plenamente del juego y puede restarle valor a la experiencia general.

Otro problema importante con Child of Light es que simplemente no es compatible con las versiones más nuevas de Windows, como Windows 10 y 11. Esto significa que  estos sistemas operativos les resultará imposible ejecutar el juego sin encontrar una gran cantidad de fallos y errores. Esto es inaceptable, dado que muchos jugadores se han actualizado a estos nuevos sistemas en los últimos años y deberían poder jugar sus juegos sin ningún problema.

En general, aunque Child of Light tenía el potencial para ser un gran juego, se ve defraudado por una serie de problemas técnicos que lo hacen muy difícil de jugar. Desde los bloqueos frecuentes hasta la incompatibilidad con los sistemas Windows más nuevos como ya explicaba antes, hay demasiados obstáculos para disfrutar plenamente de este juego. Es una verdadera lástima, ya que hay algunas imágenes hermosas y una historia potencialmente genial oculta debajo de todos estos problemas, pero desafortunadamente son demasiado importantes para pasarlos por alto. Si estás buscando un juego para jugar, sáltate Child of Light y elige otro que no te cause tantos problemas.

A very good and unique game for a small price.

1- I love strategic RPG games; the hybrid combat mechanics (turn-based and real-time) make for an innovative gameplay that is so captivating. The only downside is the difficulty; once you get a hold of the mechanics, you never have to use potions anymore; even with the hardest difficulty.

2- I'm less into pIatformers, but the fact that you get the fly ability quite early made me enjoy thoses parts. You can fly and heal yourself pretty much at anytime (without items) during platforming and exploration, so it is really forgiving.

3- I found the story not that refreshing. Nevertheless, the way that it is told in such a poetic way made it very enjoyable to read. Rubella was the perfect Harlequin.

4- The game takes less than 10 hours to complete even if you wander around trying to gather all the loot. There's a NewGame+ feature, which is nice; the thing is that the combats start to feel pretty repetitive once you have unlocked the Late Game abilities.

5- The graphics fit the story. Everything is quite lovely and all the areas have their own unique flavor.

In the end, if you love turn-based RPG games with refreshing mechanics and forgiving platformers, you will be delighted by this game. Stay away if you are a hardcore gamer who likes intense challenges.

9/10

Addendum: The game is way more poetic in french since it was made in Montréal.

128422736.review:
***
Tl; dr: A short game that feels very long due to repetitive combat and exploration mechanics. Beautiful visuals are not enough to balance out the bad, cringe-y writing, long grinding for XP and bland skill trees.

***

Child of Light is a game with RPG and platforming elements which is charming for a while despite atrocious writing. Its important weaknesses quickly outweighs its strengths, though. It's not SO bad but, in my opinion, many other titles will give you a better experience for the time you invest in them. 


PROS
+ Visually beautiful world with hand-drawn environments and characters. Nice enough that it pushed me past the point when gameplay stopped being interesting.
+ Some original battle mechanics using the mouse to slow enemies or heal allies. Fun for a while. 
+ Battle music feels epic and OST carries a strong emotional vibe. 

CONS
- All those strengths become weaknesses due to the incredibly repetitive nature of the game. It's not really a long RPG, but it does feel very long because of this.
- All dialogues are written in rhymes and, in my opinion, it is really bad! Writing is contrived, unnatural and cheap. Even if I'm not a fan, rhymed dialogue can be well-written. Not this game! If you're a writer yourself or just in love with good writing, you will probably cringe a lot.  
- Too many characters with too little differences in gameplay. About halfway through, I stopped caring entirely about the skill points I spent, since it all comes down to the same gameplay over and over, with the exception of one "true" mage with some useful elemental magic. Other characters' specialities were easily replicated by vast amounts of consumable items, or shared between multiple characters. 
- Simple crafting system becomes uninteresting quickly. Once you get some strong elemental "oculi" to slot in your weapons and armours (for damage or protection), it really just becomes a chore of equipping the right damage type for the right enemy. Rinse and repeat over, and over, and over...  

+/- The predictable story is not strong enough to carry the player through all this, despite some fun moments. A nice touch here is the fact that each new character joining the party will trigger a series of introduction dialogues, one with each other character present. Those will happen one at a time after each combat encounter until the whole party had a chance to discuss with this new party member.

6.8/10 Lesser than the sum of its parts

An Ubisoft Montréal game, bought in 2015 and finally played in 2022. For the first time in a long while, Uplay didn't bring me much trouble on launching the game.

I didn't play for the RPG, but to see the art, which I am satisfied with. The briefing was in stained glass style, I was able to quickly control my character Aurora, more story to be told along the road. The art in the background looks good for a game in 2014, well acceptable even limited by the graphic quality, no empty spaces yet not too complicated, everything looks natural. 

The map is rich and hard to find the border- I can almost always fly higher in the sky or down lower ground. My favorite is the sea world, though it is odd to see a boar boss waiting. I enjoyed the scene about bidding goodbyes to the party, and young Aurora and her mother at the blossom apple tree. They were well made and emotional. The music was fascinating, one of the highlights but the game still has some distance to Gris in my view.

The RPG battle part is plain, I find it highly repeated, luckily most battles can be avoided. The skill tree is basic, whoever reaches the bar faster gets to attack, I manage to attack twice before an enemy can hit me and it helps. A battle can last long, and I got level up after each of them. Aurora can have companions to join the party, it is up to the player to finish their requests or not. Since requests are about looking for someone, which means one more member to join the party, but you can only have 2 to fight together. The game has few items so not really worth searching for any treasure box, and Aurora only has one suit.

90% of the puzzles are either box pushing or casting light on objects to make the shadow fit, very basic and suitable for kids. And things become much faster after Aurora learnt to fly, fast travel is allowed at any time. 

At the end it feels like The Magic Flute + The Snow White storyline, took me 4 hours to finish just the right time before things get boring.

[i]Originally posted on [url=http://www.dragon-quill.net/child-of-light-2/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

Child of Light is an RPG whose battle system intrigued me. It expands on Final Fantasy‘s ATB system to make it more tactical and engaging instead of just a reskinned initiative system — though, in the circular nature of things, it actually bears a lot of similarity to FF4’s original ATB system. I’ll tentatively recommend it, but only if you’re particularly interested in RPG battle systems.

Like in Final Fantasy, characters all have a standard wait time between turns, which progresses in real time and is based on their speed stat. The twist is that every action takes additional time to execute, and if a character is damaged while casting, they are interrupted and set back in the timeline. Most strategies revolve around timing your attacks so that you interrupt enemies while avoiding being interrupted yourself, and there are additional abilities that can slow or knock back characters as well.

What I consider to be the best innovation of the game is that it makes the real-time aspect actually matter: There is a mechanic where you can move the exposition fairy around the battlefield to generate special effects if he illuminates a character. This adds an element of real-time movement to an otherwise fully turn-based system, which I think is a neat idea.

Unfortunately, the implementation of all of this leaves much to be desired. The firefly effect for heroes is health regeneration while the effect for enemies is slowing them down, and these two effects are not balanced at all: the healing is so minuscule that it’s always a better choice to mitigate damage by slowing enemies instead.

The other thing that feels very off is that characters always travel the full length of the “cast” portion of the timeline, with casting time only affecting the speed at which they do so. This makes it very hard to judge where a character will end up relative to others, which is particularly bad when battles revolve around executing your actions before your opponents. I think it would have been much more logical to have everyone travel at the same rate but end at different points, probably denoted by notches on the “cast” bar corresponding to each tier of casting time. It would also have been nice if enemies explicitly declared their casting times instead of you having to puzzle out how your casting times compare.

Unrelated to all of this, there is another mechanic I’d like to highlight: Your equipment can be equipped to any slot (weapon, armor, or accessory), with different effects for each. I found this to be a clever way to get more depth out of equipment by making you think of multiple ways to use the same item. There is also a crafting mechanic where you can combine three of the same item to upgrade to a higher tier, or combine different items to create a new item with a special effect. This was interesting, though you’ll fairly quickly discover all the possible combinations and from there it’s just a matter of upgrading them into “the same, but more”, which took a lot of the spark out of it.

The game is ultimately fairly enjoyable and still has more to engage with than a typical jRPG, but overall I felt it needed more time in the oven. I’m also not sure it has enough depth to carry the whole playtime; by the late game I found myself using the exact same strategies and the battles became very repetitive, made worse by the fact there’s not much enemy diversity.

The difficulty is also very weird; I played on hard mode because I find most RPGs too easy, and this was fine for a while but turned frustrating in the late game, where enemies do ridiculous amounts of damage with blisteringly fast attacks that constantly interrupt you and give you no time to recover. (Apparently, the fan consensus is that normal mode is way too easy and hard mode is way too hard, with no middle ground.) Despite this, I never used more than a handful of the dozens and dozens of consumable items the game hands you at every opportunity. Maybe if they had been instant, but when they have the same casting time as your regular support moves, there’s not much incentive.

And, minor, but the main character is weirdly weak? Statwise she’s a jack-of-all-trades and therefore master of none, except for her HP which is even lower than the squishy wizard’s. Even her particular niche, light magic, is mostly irrelevant thanks to equipment that makes regular attacks light-elemental. For most of the game I benched her in favor of specialists who could fight more effectively. Possibly this is intentional to reflect how young she is? But still odd.

Storywise… this is one of the very few times I’ll say “Play the game, skip the story.” All dialogue is written in rhyming scheme — every single line — which requires everything to be contorted into painfully tortured wording because English fundamentally is not designed for that. Many scenes are borderline incomprehensible. And this might just be me, but the obvious artifice of it makes it impossible for me to take anything seriously — it feels like the characters are, well, acting out a script rather than real people experiencing real emotions. Immersion is totally broken.

The actual plot itself is deliberately cliche, though not painfully so. It’s a rough adaptation of Snow White with some elements of Sleeping Beauty, reimagined as a portal fantasy. There is a slightly clever twist midway through, though it’s pretty easy to see coming, and the ending does not pull an “it was all a dream/metaphor” like I was fearing. It’s overall unobjectionable aside from the rhyming scheme thing, but that’s about all I have to say.

A fun JRPG style platformer (you can fly!) with a artistic visuals. This is an older game, so be prepared for the lack of quality of life improvements to could be made, especially where focus was on aesthetics over functionality. This game has been recently updated though, so there is still hope for updates. There are a lot of characters and "classes" to choose from, but I primarily focused on ain heroine - including dumping all the permanent stat bonuses her. Combat is based on a 2 v 4 party system, but you can swap out your characters in your party, whereas the enemy have fixed monsters.

There is no standard equipment system, but instead you have gems; you have elemental gems that can be combined and upgraded, with three gem slots to use. The slots are offence, defence, and utility. You can mix and match the gems used in the slots, and there is no cost involved. The offensive gem can change the element of the physical attack, while the defensive gem and give elemental resistance.

- see equipment (gems) in battle
- see whole party, to drag and drop gems all from one screen
- setting for disabling music when game in background
- rearrange party outside of battle
- grimoire for monsters, including their stats, skills, weaknesses, strengths etc
- menu wheel for battles is impractical, please let us have a standard one inside a box; same with gem selection

[h1] A modern work of Art [/h1]
It’s quite rare that a game, or any piece of art, makes me tear up, but I couldn’t help crying at the end.

I had almost forgotten how beautiful it is.
I felt every conversation, every emotion, every win and every loss Aurora and her friends had during this adventure. 
The Artstyle is so unique and brilliant - the watercolour background and characters look so stunning and truly pull you into the world of Lemuria. The rhyming in the dialogue makes you feel like you're watching a Shakespeare play, it just works so well in this universe. The story is one of a kind; its touching, meaningful and teaches you important things about life. 
Like standing up for your believes, that good always wins over evil, and that even when all hope is lost, there’s always a way out. It is a story about maturing, love and true friendship. 
A story about a child that only wants to find a way home but ends up fighting for the greater good. The music and sound-design really round it up, especially the credits song. 
With its incredible story, stunning visuals and outstanding music, Child of Light managed to gain a place in my heart. And it will probably reside there forever.
Even my most beloved games have some flaws, but I don’t see any flaws here. Maybe that it was too short, but that gives it its special feeling. 
I enjoyed every minute of it, and I think it was worth every penny I’ve paid. Hell, I would pay the price of a triple A title for this game.
This is probably the best game I’ve ever played, and it will most likely remain the best. Sometimes I wish you could turn back time, or erase the memory of something, so that you can experience it for the first time all over again. But that would ruin the magic and the moment of experiencing something, and especially this game, for the first time. 
For anyone who hasn’t played this already. Do yourself a favour and experience it for the first time. If you played this game a long time ago, revisit it. I promise you will not regret it. 
I’ve yet to find another game that is even remotely close to this one. It’s likely that only a sequel, which we will unfortunately never get, will take the crown. 
While having cool BR games, which provide long term services is good, I think this is what a videogame can and should truly be - a modern work of art

Pretty decent puzzle platformer with JRPG combat. There are a couple quirks that make it stand out. For one thing, all the equippable items are gems that you either get from killing monsters or opening chests. All your consumables are found in chests. There is no currency and no shops. If you're the kind of person that holds on to limited items and never uses them, this could be a bit of a hassle.

There are a wide range of party members, but you can only have two in play at a time. They all get xp whether or they're not in a given fight, which is nice. Every time a character levels, it gets a flat stat bonus, in addition to a talent point you can fiddle with. Each character only has one gimmick that they focus on more or less, so you have to get used to juggling party members. Need healing? Swap in the healer. Need tanking? Swap in the tank. It's pretty painless, but takes a little getting used to.

One of the main gimmicks is that you get a fairy that moves on the screen independent of your character, either using the mouse or the right thumbstick. Using fairy juice, you can either slow enemies or regenerate health for allies, and most of the puzzles in platforming center around activating things with the fairy. 

There's a world map with fast travel, but I really would have liked area maps as well, as there's a lot of stuff to collect and you can easily miss things if you don't explore thoroughly. 

I enjoyed the graphics of the game, which were all beautifully hand painted watercolors. Also, all the dialogue is in rhyming verse.

All told, worth buying, but you might want to wait for a sale. It's only about 10 hours long.

Child of light is a beautiful game that follows the story of Aurora from a young girl as she grows into her destiny as a young woman. I bought this game for my daughter when she was about 10yo as I wanted something suitable for her level of gaming. This game turned out to be an amazingly good choice for her. 

Child of Light has elements of other games - making decisions about where to allocate skill points to level up through skill trees, crafting recipes, different types of damage, increasingly hard enemies - but with turn-based combat that lets a younger gamer proceed at her own pace. To pass through the levels you have to solve puzzles and combat enemies to get to the final battle and your destiny.  Aurora is accompanied by a firefly who lights her way and guides her. Along the way she gathers other companions that will help in her quests and battles.  

The art style is incredibly gorgeous and the story is well crafted and touching - it's like you are playing through a beautiful fairy tale storybook. The musical score as well is wonderful. 

It is a testament to Child of Light that my daughter has played it through several times and now she is 18 she has returned to play through the story once more while she waits for university to start. 

Child of Light is a timeless work of art. Recommended, especially for younger gamers.

99867708.review:
Child of Light is a side-scrolling, turn-based RPG in which you control a little red-haired princess named Aurora. The side-scrolling aspect is especially fun, because you can fly. It's the perfect game for those who like to explore beautiful worlds. And beautiful it is, this world called Lemuria, hand-painted with watercolors with papery texture to boot. 

So there's a lot of style in this title, but not as a means to compensate for low quality game play. That's not to say the game play is especially profound. While the exploring is fun, and the world is filled with little puzzles and a ton of loot, most of the loot has little impact on your method of play. Healing items are good for boss fights, but most of them go unused. You have a firefly friend who can illuminate different areas of the map, allowing you to find more treasures. 

There's no shopping in this game, and your only equipment comes in the form of gems called Oculi, which can be crafted and combined from their different varieties. After each level-up, your characters get to choose different upgrades, which is cool, but your characters are all going to have their general strengths and weaknesses, even with permanent stat-boosters. Characters also pool experience, so the fun exploration often gets halted so you can stop and choose upgrades for these characters you never use, but might need... maybe. 

The characters themselves aren't especially interesting, but I didn't look too deeply into it. Why not? Well, there's something about this game which I really can't stand. The developers decided to make every single line of dialogue rhyme. And the rhyming is bad. Almost every sentence reads like it was spoken by Yoda, causing most of the text to come out in a jumble of terrible sentence structure. I figure on every block, there's a kid rapper who could have done a better job. 

The battle system for this game is pretty good. It's much like Grandia, in the way that all fighters share a time bar. Each action takes a certain amount of time to execute, which gives you and your enemies space to interrupt each other. This is all swell, but a lot of enemies counter attack when you interrupt them, others counter when you use physical, magical, or elemental attacks. Each enemy has its own mode, which you need to keep in mind. This is fun, but there are no quick battles. They all require a certain level of focus, causing you to, after upgrading your characters, forget where you're going. 

Looping back to the subject of elemental magic, I'm not really a fan of it, especially when you don't have all the elements at your disposal. Most RPG games have the tree levels, where everything's weak to fire, then the fire world, then the water world, and so forth, in an order you're never aware of. And this works fine (albeit lazy), so long as you're not forced to use elemental magic, and don't have to gamble on which magic to learn. 

The music in this game is all right, fitting, but there are only about four songs in it. But even that's fine, since it only took me twelve hours to finish this game. Despite it's flaws, I think Child of Light is a good game. It doesn't make you do boring things, like talk to every single person in town before getting to it. The game play is immersive, with the perfect amount of complexity. Some of the battles are also pretty hard, which scratches an itch. It would have been better if they'd included some impossible fights that, in spite of your perfect strategy, require you to come back later. 

Child of Light's pretty good, but not really my kind of RPG. It's magical and whimsical, and more for the 90s born fairy tale fans instead of us who grew up worshiping Japanese games. I've watched Brandon Sanderson's lectures on Fantasy writing, and many of his concepts apply to all forms of media. Every story opens with a promise about what kind of experience the consumer is going to have. And if that promise isn't fulfilled, the readers (or players) will be unsatisfied. Despite its challenges, I think Child of Light is too short. It puts a lot of systems in play that are never used to their remote capacity. There are some touching moments to its story, but its resolution is flacid, and crowded with one-note, boring party members. 

Style: 4/5 - Substance: 2/5 - Music: 3/5 - Fun: 4/5

Child of Light is one of the most enjoyable and beautiful games I've played to date.  Its heartwarming visuals, its tales of loss and conquering one's fears, its fun battle system, and its gorgeous orchestral soundtrack form a perfect combination that leaves me grinning from ear to ear just thinking about it years later.  It's a children's book, drawn in watercolor, with nonsensical rhymes and the freedom to experience it all in a relaxing way or crank up the difficulty to challenge yourself hard.

Exploration is done by platforming with Aurora (the main character) and interacting through obstacles/puzzles with her companion Igniculus -- both M+KB and traditional gamepad work well to use these two distinctive, yet simultaneous types of action.  As you experience this beautiful and whimsy world first as a basic platformer and, soon after, with full flying mobility, you will encounter enemies in the field.

Combat is innovative but straight-forward with a mix of turn-based actions where everyone is able to interrupt the opponent's turns or get more themselves.  The simultaneous actions you saw on the field show up here again with Aurora's companion able to help slow enemies or heal your allies, while you are also controlling your fighters.  It's fun, but a tad easy in normal difficulty, standard speed settings.  It's when you increase the difficulty and crank up the speed that the combat really shines.  Interrupting and buffing/debuffing stop being just "neat" and they become the only way to survive, while strategizing when your allies should take action to deal with the upcoming enemy turns becomes a serious challenge.  Any turn wasted can become fatal.

And as all this happens, a truly unforgettable soundtrack plays in the background, giving a sense of place and a focus to every scene that is just perfect.

Delightful at every moment and with the right length: not too short, not too long.  If you have not experienced Child of Light, you are missing out.

Translating a game that tries to pass as poetry is SUPER hard, but they did what they could VERY professionally. And the voice actress for Brazilian Portuguese did a BRILLIANT, fantastic job. Back to the actual review now!)

The whole mood of the game is very "meh". While the artists are very capable and talented, the world they created feel dull. I'm not here to see great technique. I'm here to be drawn into this world, I'm here to say "wow, that is an incredible idea", "woah, I would never think THAT". Instead I'm just saying "oh, artist number 5 did a great job adjusting the colors to artist number 3's enemies, and I guess artists 9 through 12 really did make movement look beautiful". I'm never invited into the world with just my eyes. (Side note number two: the character development is good enough. I won't review this separately, but they range from "meh" to "good".)

The composer uses the main leitmotif WAY too much. It's not that good, for starters, and it also doesn't really help with storytelling. Sure, it is connected to Aurora (the main character) and her mom, but PLEASE don't shove and reference it in EVERY OTHER AREA. Seriously. It loses its meaning. "Oh, it's sad because Lemuria and the story are sad", "oh, it plays everywhere because [SPOILERS] Aurora is the rightful heir to this currently-ravished land [END OF SPOILERS]". Well, I don't care, use it in more clever ways, then. Spice it up with something other than different orchestration. Change the tempo, the dynamics, use percussion instruments. Maybe hide it here and there subtly. Make me interested. Be clever. There are many ways to do it, but they were avoided. The composer was surely able to do a better job. I'm blaming Ubisoft, because, well, fuck them. They probably didn't pay the composer enough.

Oh: the game is TOO easy in casual mode and too hard in expert. The Igniculus is a great device to gain advantage in battles, but there absolutely should be another difficulty between those two. I NEVER died during the whole game. One character fell in battle three times in total (and was promptly revived in the following turn). I was never on the edge of my seat, I never felt in danger. The game is smart in teaching you how to battle, but it never throws a curveball.

The only really good thing Child of Light does is battle. The battle system is a gorgeous little thing that can be quite fun (and using a mouse-and-controller combination works beautifully. The mouse is the perfect substitute to the Wii U gamepad's touch screen). Not much to say here, it's just super good. I wish the whole game was half as good as its battle system.

Lastly, screw this company for shoving Uplay and Ubisoft Connect with the game. "Oh, they gave you the DLC for 'free' when you made an account", I DON'T WANT TO make an account and I also don't want the damn DLC, I want to sit on my chair, run Steam and then run the game. Just that. So fuck them for this too.

To wrap things up: I obviously DON'T recommend this game. Buy something else. Indie games, preferrably. If you really, really, REALLY want to play it, find a way to play that doesn't give any money to Ubisoft. I'm sure you're smart and creative enough. If you aren't, maybe they'll give it away on Epic someday, I don't know and don't care, just don't give them your money, it's never worth it, especially for this game.

Score: 3/10

I'm a gaming newbie and Child of Light is the first title I got completely invested in. Fuelled by a nostalgia for turn-based combat and old school RPGs, I gave this a shot and by the end, I was cheering for even the side characters and hated the bad guys with a fury that I didn’t know I had in me. If you enjoy fantasy/turn-based RPG games, this one's for you. 

[b] STORY & SCRIPT [/b]: Overall, not what you wouldn’t expect from a bedtime fantasy tale but with plenty of interesting twists to make it something else. Busts countless traditional genre conventions, for instance in its approach to courtly love, power structures and having a bittersweet ever after. All of this is never done cynically. Without giving away too much, I will say this game has a reality-bending aspect to it; you wouldn't expect so much for a small indie title like this one. Finally, the rhyming script doesn't work everywhere but it gives the game a lot of heart.

[b] GAMEPLAY [/b]: The real-time element gives life to the turn-based combat, especially in expert mode. I didn’t expect this kind of combat to make me care more about the characters but it did. Learning their different skills, crafting and equipping oculi and watching them get better over time really personalised the experience. I started in normal difficulty mode. By the last chapter, if you don't play in expert mode, the challenge factor is lost.

[b] ARTWORK [/b]: Each map location is lovingly hand-painted in contrasting watercolour themes. This carries the game’s ethereal aesthetic; even though Aurora is a badass warrior, she flutters fluidly around Lemuria in a delicate gown (one can do both). I can’t remember how many screenshots I took.

[b] ANIMATION [/b]: The few scenes that utilize 3D camera shots are hair-raising, especially toward the end. The characters’ body language gives each scene added emotional depth- I found myself wincing at a character's pain just by seeing how they braced themselves.

[b] SOUNDTRACK [/b]: Let me just say it brought me to tears. On multiple occasions. The music is perfection.

Overall, Child of Light is a hidden masterpiece, achieving all that it set out to do (and more) excellently. Due to its strong genre elements and old school RPG gameplay, you’ll either love it or you won’t. I cherish every second I spent gliding in Lemuria. To me, Aurora will forever be the Queen of Light.

In 2014 Ubisoft published 5 AAA games, which led to the humorous article 'Ubisoft Game: The Review' written by Tim Colwill. In short the article pokes fun at Ubisoft and these 5 AAA games for despite being from different franchises are all very similar in terms of characters, story, game play mechanics etc. 

In the same year however, Ubisoft also published two indie titles, Valiant Hearts: The Great War and this one Child of Light. Despite both being both short, cheap indie games, I would take these two over any copy paste AAA title the company publishes.

Child of Light mixes a traditional turn based RPG battle system with a side scrolling exploration including platforming and puzzle solving. 

When it comes to turn based battle systems, I feel like I am in the minority of people who still enjoy this style of combat. With many mainstream RPG's favouring more action based combat. However, I feel turn based combat can still be enjoyable as long as there is at least some attempt at innovation. Child of Lights innovation on the combat revolves around the ability to actively slow down enemies and speed up allies both before and during actions. This slow down speed up mechanic is further utilised by the fact that certain spells and abilities can be interrupted. This applies to both enemies and allies, so sometimes you will want to speed up ally to get their spell off quicker, other times you will want to slow down an enemy casting so you can get a perfectly timed interrupt. 

Other than the combat the game boasts fantastic, music, beautiful art work on both the back drops and characters and a general feeling that passion went into its entire design, something which has become synonymous with great indie titles of which this is one.

The story takes around 12 hours to complete, adding a few more if you want collect everything. In that time you will not have to climb towers, do any stealth missions with instant failure states or look at mini map with 1000 busy work markers on it.

87367779.review:
"Child, tuck yourself in bed
and let me tell a story
of Lemuria, a long lost kingdom
and a girl born for glory"

Child of Light is a platforming role-playing video game developed by Ubisoft Montreal and published by Ubisoft.

[b]Story[/b]
Year 1895, Austria. Young girl named Aurora goes to sleep, and wakes up in a fantasy land called Lemuria, ruled by evil Queen of the Night. To return home, Aurora has to save Lemuria by bringing back the sun, the moon, and the stars.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Child of Light is a side scroller with role playing elements. Aurora and her companions travel across Lemuria, complete objectives to push story further and unlock new areas, while dealing with dangerous enemies in combat, with occasional boss fights.
Explore magical land by foot, or soar through the sky using your wings, to collect different confessions, discover secrets, and recive additional sidequests.
While you explore you can use firefly Igniculus and his magic to light up dark places, open chests out of your reach, heal yourself and shine light on enemies to stun them for an advantage or to pass them without triggering combat.

Combat itself is close to JRPG's such as Final Fantasy. Featuring similar active-time battle system, two of your teammembers can fight up to three enemies at once!
System is pretty easy to get- each alive being on screen is featured on a timeline that appears in a middle of the combat area.
Timeline is build from two sections, one is a "spectator phase", where you can see how battle goes and think about strategy (or help yourself using Igniculus as he is helpful here just as much as outside of combat) and second, smaller section where you get to choose your move and call it. You can switch characters, use potions to regenerate stats or perform an action. Everything takes specific amount of time- triggering defense or using potions is very quick, while most powerful attacks take longest amount of time to reach the end.
Enemies are seperated into elementary types, and will require a use of different attacks to beat them.
If you or your enemies get hit in a second section, while waiting for an action to happen, this action is cancelled, forcing a character to go back in the timeline. This mechanic, if used correctly and if you will have a bit of luck, will let you win battles without taking a scratch!
It might sound like a lot when it comes to combat, but belive me that in game it's pretty easy to get and you shouldn't have any issues with figuring it out. Especially as game features good tutorial for it!
After done combat you get experience points, if you collected enough you level up granting you a skill point available to spend on skill trees, plus sometimes you gather potions and/or ocuilis- magical crystals you can equip for your characters to grant them additional bonuses!

[b]Pros and Cons[/b]
Easily my favourite part is dialogue. Game takes inspiration from many poems, with majority of the dialogue being portrayed through rhymes delivered in ballad form. A rather uncommon element in games, which here with the fantasy setting works wonders.
Add to that beautiful watercolour art style achieved thanks to UbiArt Framework Engine, and optimistic, romantic soundtrack composed by Béatrice Martin, also known as Cœur de pirate, to get one fantastic presentation.
All those elements pretty much motivate to explore and make it very pleasant, dosen't matter if you travel through the spider infested caves or fly across the sky.
And when you don't explore, engaging yet easy to get turn based combat will keep your interest!
Plus it's worth mentioning that Child of Light to spice things up offers even occasional puzzles and platformic sections where your flight is affected by wind, or lava.

I've had a little issue with difficulty. Game offers only "Casual" or "Veteran" modes, lacking good middleground that could balance the combat.
And skill trees could be a bit...smaller. Even for Ubisoft standards it's too much.
With each character having over 70 skills available seperated into 3 paths, amount of them is simply overwhelming and forces you to grind if you want all of them.
In first few hours after every single combat you recive a skill point, raising a question of "Why so many skills is there?".

[b]Playtime, replayability and other gamemodes[/b]
Child of Light takes 10-15 hours to complete, depending on how much you will explore and how swiftly you will make through the combat.
Game allows you to continue playing after credits roll if you want to grind your characters or finish any side quests left, giving it additional replayability!
It features cooperation mode where second player can control Igniculus, to help in combat and exploration.

[b]Additional information[/b]
Ubisoft Connect is required to launch and play this title.

[b]Final words and conclusion[/b]
I would welcome a teased sequel-prequel with open arms, but with Ubi changing their gaming approach like a wind I doubt that will happen, unfortunately. They probably forgot about it anyway because last time they teased it was back in 2018 when CoL hit Nintendo Switch.
Just like with Valiant Hearts, even if you are not a Ubi fan I suggest checking out this title.

Child of Light is an excellent game, with superb visuals and soundtrack, enjoyable gameplay and well-written story. Highly recommended!

You also don't get lost, looking for some random item that's not in an obvious place and constantly going back and forth to the same locations. In fact, the game prompts you wonderfully, so you don't miss things. The end result is that you can relax and enjoy exploring this beautiful world and constantly progressing.

That said, the turn-based combat has a few twists, including a timing mechanism (similar to some Final Fantasy chapters) and using your firefly companion to help, which adds another touch of real time to the fighting. Also, only two can fight at any one time, but you can swap them out during combat. And even the combat manages to look pretty!

I often find there to be too much dialogue in games (especially RPGs), and this is no exception. However, because of the way the game prompts you, describes open goals in your inventory pretty clearly, and generally puts things in front of you, you rarely miss important things if you skip through or forget what you read. Also, the central narrative is pretty surprising and cute. One complaint: the characters speak in rhyme, and this can get annoying -- but like I said, feel free to skip through and enjoy the beautiful exploration.

It's a shame this game isn't more widely known or praised. It's a classic. If you enjoy visually stunning and hand-drawn material, and if you want a game to be several hours long without being frustratingly hard, this game is a great fit. :)

Child of Light is a beautiful and poetic game, with a unique fairy-tale feel to it. 

[b]Visuals & Soundtracks[/b]
This game looks so cute! The artwork looks like illustrations out of a fairy tale book. The music is so beautiful, and really conveys the sadness and melancholy of the story. Paired together, music & visuals really give you that unique vibe the game is going for.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay is really good, the battle system in particular is surprisingly tactical. It starts off as a classic JRPG's ATB, with characters waiting for their turn to play, and the ability to swap your teammates in-battle (think Final Fantasy 10 for those who've played it). 
But to that you add the possibility of interrupting enemies before they can perform their actions, and being able to delay the ATB bar of a chosen enemy in real-time. That means you always have something to do, even when waiting for your turn to play. 
Each character has a unique set of abilities that makes them better suited to dealing with a certain kind of enemy, or a certain situation, which means you'll have to use each of your teammates at the right moment to win.

[b]Story[/b]
This is a sort of fairy tale, and the story goes hand-in-hand with the visuals and the music. All the characters speak in rhymes, which is delightful. It carries some nice themes, like what it means to grow up, and what defines a home. However, I think the story is maybe a bit too simplistic at times, especially at the end which by the way feels a little rushed. It's not a deal-breaker, more of a missed opportunity, I think.

All in all, I really recommend it! This game is something special and unique that will speak to your inner child.

74481418.review:
This game seems very overhyped in my opinion. This just seems to be a below average JRPG (turn-based game).

While I am not exactly an expert on JRPG's, I do know that the standard party size for most JRPG's is 4. Generally speaking,  the party consists of the tank, healer, physical DPS, and magic DPS. In Child of Light, your party can only consist of 2 characters while in battle, but you can switch out characters at any point during your turn without wasting your turn. This effectively removes the need for a healer or tank. After all, if one of your characters takes too much damage, then you just switch out to one of your other characters. You can also rely on level ups to fully heal your party. You don't even have to have any strategy for this (e.g. skip normal encounters so that beating the boss will always level you up). I fought every enemy I encountered and never back-tracked in order to grind, and I leveled up like every 3 battles. So you really don't have to worry about the damage your party takes.

This means you never really need to build your characters for defense, just offense, which severely limits the customization potential of your party. You simply have to find out how the character can do the most damage, and put your skill points in that direction. This isn't even that hard because every character can only go in 3 linear paths in their skill tree. The best path is often fairly obvious. E.g. for a mage, do you want to go through the skill tree path that gives a 30% passive damage boost to all his spells or a better melee physical attack? 

To be fair, JRPG's are not just about offense and defense. They're also about the status effects. However, there are very few status effects in this game, and even fewer status effects that you're going to want to use. I would say 80% of the stat boosts I used were either increasing the speed of my characters or lowering the speed of the enemy characters. The other 20% (usually boss fights) involved giving a damage boost to the most effective DPS for that boss or a status effect which stopped my party members from getting any negative status effects. So like 4 status effects….. That's not a lot.

It should also be noted that there's no loot/equipment in this game. Instead, you get gems which you can socket into 3 places (weapon, armor, accessory) which gives you various passive benefits. You can combine gems to form bigger gems that provide bigger bonuses. Unfortunately, the bonuses that these gems provide are so minimal (e.g. -20% physical damage) and so unnecessary (because the game isn't that difficult/complex to warrant you needing those gems) that I was never excited to get new gems. In the beginning, the main benefit they provided was to change the elemental damage of your physical attack (fire, lightning, and water). This was fairly useful since some enemies are weak and/or resistant against certain elemental attacks, so this can be a significant damage boost. However, you never have to actively change your gems because like I mentioned, you can change your characters at any time. So as long you have 2 party members with fire, lightning, and water damage each, you're all set.

The RPG elements in this game are simply far too shallow. I never got a satisfying feeling of building the perfect party in order to deal with any challenge I would face. That just leaves the combat as far as gameplay is concerned, and while it is admittedly kind of interesting, it gets boring very quickly. All characters, players and enemies included, take action based on a speed system. You can always see where any character is in the order of turns. When it's the character's turn, they decide what move to make, and each move takes varying degrees of time to cast (short, medium, long, very long). If a character takes damage while channeling a move, they'll be "interrupted" and fall back on the timeline and have to wait to perform a move all over again. You can also use your mouse to slow down one enemy's speed. It was fairly fun in the beginning mastering the system and being able to take like 10 turns in a row as I consistently interrupted a boss's attack. However, it got old fast because I fundamentally used the same strategy over and over again:
	• 1 enemy (including bosses): Constantly interrupt them. If you do it properly, they'll maybe get 1 or 2 attacks in for the entire battle. Easy as hell.
	• 2 enemies: Prioritize 1 enemy to kill using the characters most effective to kill them (e.g. physical or magic damage and fire, lightning, or water damage). They should die in like 2-3 hits without getting even 1 attack off. Then kill the last enemy who should be easy to kill.
	• 3 enemies: Use a move to slow down all enemies and re-apply it if needed. Prioritize 1 enemy to kill and swap around party members (i.e. because you'll likely take a few hits since at 3 enemies, you can't effectively interrupt all of them) until it's dead. Proceed to use the strategy for 2 enemies and then the one for 1 enemy.

There's a story, but I didn't really care for it. You play as a little girl who's on a quest to return to her father and save him from an evil queen. Along the way, you'll meet your party members who have various side-stories themselves. The problem with the story is that pretty much all the stories are self-contained. The side-stories baaaaaaarely have anything to do with the main story at hand (apart from "the evil queen caused this bad thing to happen to me. Please help me fix this bad thing"). So it's like you spend 1 hour focusing on 1 story, then 1 hour on a completely different story, etc… This means I simply did not get attached to any of the characters and therefore did not end up caring what happened. I'll admit that the little girl you play as is cute, and it's cute how everyone talks in rhymes, but that's about it (i.e. I'll admit the characters and the story are cute).

In conclusion, there's just very little to sink your teeth into with this game. The RPG elements are really shallow, the combat gets very repetitive very fast, and the story is all over the place and at best it's the standard "defeat the evil villain with the power of friendship" story.

69694234.review:
Lots of games nowadays play with nostalgia, but 'Child of Light' (2014) manages to evoke a particular mood that's hard to put into words. It goes back deeper to an earlier phase in my life. That warm feeling from times past when one of your parents read you a story from a picture book. In that wondrous state of almost falling asleep and being most impressionable for mood shifts in mom's or dad's voice.  Sometimes you cackle from laughter because something silly pops up. Sometimes you gaze at the beautiful drawings of hyperrealistic worlds where the grass is greener than green and the sea bluer than blue. Those otherworldy places where magical creatures (talking animals, fairies, trolls, ogres) look so different and yet so much like ourselves. Those magical places that throw difficulties and opportunities to a princess that can leave everything behind in her flight upwards. Sometimes you notice a sense of dread or sadness which feels out of tune with the innocent story that is being told. Not seldom was a night's sleep wasted over a story that inadvertently touched on more serious subjects like failure, fear, loss or even death and decay. 

Being a thirty-something I occasionaly re-experience the joy of picture books through reading them for younger family members. For a vivid reader like myself it's a humbling thought that a good story doesn't need much to be gripping, as long as it knows how to strike the right chords to trigger your own imagination. I felt a similar joy while playing 'Child of Light' (2014) as a coming-of-age story of a princess who is blossoming towards maturity in a far-away land. Her journey both epic and small at the same time. I especially love its simple aesthetics as a blend of 2D- and 3D-animation and how the levels are designed with all these small visual treats. There's always something going on in the fore- or background like creatures flying around or weather elements and light effects filling the screen. All so vibrant and lively. Maybe the best part is the soundtrack by Béatrice Martin/Coeur de Pirate, whose usage of choirs make it feel that there is all the more at stake in Aurora's inner battles. Genuinely moving at times. 

Gameplay-wise, the game offers enough tactical options for crafting with elementals or (re-) equipping your characters to let them have the upperhand in battles. Due to the large variety of side-characters, you have many different approaches how to go into a fight. Though I'm not a big fan of skill grids, and I did feel that a large portions of the game become repetitive because it had me swapping through menu's. Another small gripe is that once you get further on the skill grid, you find that future attacks are either stronger versions of those you already have or they affect more enemies at the same time. The variety really comes with the amount of playable characters and not so much from their individual skills.

There's much to love about how 'Child of Light' (2014) taps both into the simple, innocent joy of being a child and the bittersweetness of lost youth. Thoroughly befitting as a hymn to those bedtime stories that offered some light in a world that's sometimes hard to grasp. Under the watchful eye of a mom or dad who tucked you in and let you be with your dreams and hopes. All possibilities still open.

I got into the game with low expectations, but was amazed! Child of Light is a simple turn-based RPG game. Although I am not into turn-based games in general, I enjoyed this one very much.

First things first, the art is just absolutely stunning!! It's unique and simple, yet effective. Along with the amazing soundtrack (especially the ending song omg!!) they compensate for the shortage of narration throughout the story for me. The story itself with the side quests are basic and nothing unique about them. Nonetheless, I found myself attached to the characters until the end. The ending was kinda rushed but I was fine with it.

The game mechanics are simple. The timeline idea with firefly helping you in real-time was a nice touch differentiating it from other turn-based games. The crafting and leveling systems are easy to understand too. Maybe my only issue with the gameplay is how you get some of the characters late in-game. There is not enough time to experiment with them unless you're grinding. Also, there is not an option to select your party before starting any battle. Although they make up for this by not penalizing party changes mid-battle, but still I found it annoying.

The game has initially two difficulties: story one and expert. Just that. Nothing in between! I found that strange. The expert mode is challenging and sometimes irritating, especially if you're putting your skill points blindly as I did early in-game XD. But once you figure out the roles of each character in your party and how to utilize their abilities effectively, the game becomes much easier.

Although some of my comments above, the game is worth playing especially since it's a short one. You can't go wrong with the visuals and the soundtrack <3!

Child of Light is a sweet game with a plot reminiscent of a fairy tale. I personally enjoyed playing it, as the game mechanics were fairly simple to learn. It reminded me a bit of other favorites of mine, yet I still found it original.

The plot isn't groundbreaking, but it had enough charm to keep me hooked. I personally think the story's main strength is its world-building. It's very unique and contains just enough depth to be believable.

The art and the music are what make this game stand out. I couldn't get enough of guiding Aurora through all the beautiful watercolor backgrounds. The music can be a bit repetitive, but each track individually is gorgeous. I could listen to the soundtrack all day. Excellent for setting the tone of the game.

The only major downside for me was the dialogue. Someone decided that all the characters needed to speak in rhyme, and everyone else went along with it. Unfortunately, this was not executed well. Many of the rhymes feel forced and unnatural. As a result, some dialogue feels as if it comes out of nowhere, and other lines don't make any sense at all. I can see how some people feel that it's a necessary part of the overall atmosphere, though. I just wish more care had been put into crafting the rhymes.

Overall, I think this game is very enjoyable. If you like what you see in the trailers and screenshots, I think that's a good indicator that you'll like the game.

-------------

(Side note: don't buy the DLC. I only bought The Golem's Plight, and that was because I had a few more cents to spend, it was on sale at the time, and I thought it would be fun to have an extra character. You'll find hundreds of oculi in the game, so you won't need to buy any more with real money. The skin packs might be nice if you like the character designs, but you won't need the spells either. There are other characters in the game who already do a good job of casting those same spells. Even the Golem is debatable, as he's not a much better fighter than other characters and he doesn't add much story-wise. Don't buy unless you can think of a really good reason to.)

66977272.review:
A classic fairytale game. 

Whether you like or dislike this game will very much depend on what you’re looking to get out of it.

The developers set out to make a game feel like a classic children’s fairytale, and they completely succeeded in this sense. 

Child of the light has one of the most beautiful soundtracks in gaming, a lovely watercolour-based art style and charming writing made up entirely of poetry. 

Exploring the world utilizes all three of these aspects in a way that is incredibly satisfying, calming and relaxing. 

Years after finishing the game, images, settings and moments will stay in your memory due to how well they are crafted.

Story-wise it is very much a child’s fairy tale. It is not deep or complex. However, there are likeable characters and some good emotional moments as well.  

The gameplay combines platforming with traditional turned-based JRPG style combat and levelling. 

It is very competent in both areas. The game has a nice thematic level design and a simple but effective battle system. 

However, many other games excel far greater individually in each aspect, GRIS as an artistic platformer, for example, while the majority of JRPG’s have more complex battle and levelling systems. 

Combat is easy even on harder settings and doesn’t demand the strategy or grind that most JRPG’s require. The platforming elements are slightly more difficult than the combat but still fairly easy overall. It is in the platforming sections where the game shines the most. 

This game is at its best when taking in the music and soaking in the setting whilst exploring the world.  

If you’re looking for groundbreaking gameplay or a gripping storyline Child of the Light will disappoint you. 

On the other hand, if you have had a hard day and want to put on a beautiful, calming and relaxing game to chill out too, Child of the Light will be exceptional for you.

Additional notes 

- Exploring every area and doing every side quest takes around 25-30 hours. 
- The DLC is rather pointless and unnecessary to purchase.
- Saving is done by a regular autosave feature; there is no manual save option.
- This game requires you to install and log in via Uplay.

[b]PROS:[/b]
+ fantastic soundtrack
+ lovely fairy tale story
+ pretty art style
+ useful collectibles to look for
+ new game+ 

[b]CONS:[/b]
- uPlay
- combat timeline mechanic
- uPlay unlocks are bugged
- no online co-op

[b]Special review section for Ubisoft games:[/b]
[u]Should you play?[/u] YEP
[u]Should you BUY???[/u] YES, ON A SALE

[b]Comment:[/b]
This game is a fairy tale turn-based RPG with some platforming. While the story starts out weak it picks up later on and I got really engaged by the mid-section. Aurora as well as her companions kind of grow on you and you almost feel sad when the campaign ends. Not everyone will like it, especially with some of the weird dialogue early on, but I did (eventually). Though the highlight of this game has to be the soundtrack. Whether it is peaceful ambiance during exploring or blaring orchestra during boss fights, it all sounds wonderful. Art style is nice with very pretty drawn characters and levels. It is possible to play as two players when one controls Aurora (via keyboard or gamepad) and the second controls Igniculus "the firefly" (via mouse or 2nd gamepad). While moving the firefly precisely via gamepad is possible it is much more effective to use a mouse. This promotes having a second player around but also pushes solo players towards mouse and keyboard too. I tried both styles and while jumping is better via gamepad I preferred the accuracy of the mouse to move the firefly and once you get flight you don't jump at all. There are the only two difficulties and to truly engage with the combat system you need to try the harder one. And if you have the DLC and/or uPlay unlocks it is [u]really[/u] recommended to play on Expert because Casual difficulty becomes too trivial. That being said, I really dislike the timeline in combat and how it works. Sometimes it seems your character gets to go first only to be interrupted by the enemy who jumped in front of the queue. This is my biggest gripe with the game - the visibility of player/enemy turns. I got through it without lowering the difficulty but it sucked out the fun from some encounters. The combat itself is otherwise fun and I ended up using just about all companions for various fights. So while there was some frustration, defeating tough enemies still feels rewarding. A cool indie gem I didn't like at first ... but ended up enjoying a lot in the end!

*Note: The local-only co-op can be circumvented by using Steam Remote Play Together.

I did my playthrough on Expert from the start, since the alternative was "Casual" (I thought that meant "Easy" when, in fact, it's "Normal"). Some bosses and mini-bosses took between 5 and 10 minutes. Moreover, you will likely need to grind around 5 levels worth before trying to face the last two bosses.

+Charming fairy tale based story

+Well-suited soundtrack and effects

+Beautiful and creative environments/visuals and world building

+Great character and enemy designs

=(+?)No achievements or steam trading cards (I personally saw this as a plus because it was refreshing to just enjoy a game without having to worry about extra things)

This is disappointing to me because I feel like the sprites/models that are different would've looked so much better in the style the rest are in. It's also a little immersion breaking.

-The main antagonist, Umbra, has a glitch with her talking sprite where you can see her bald head glitch through her own hair during text transitions. This may have happened elsewhere, but if it did, I didn't notice. Umbra's glitch is glaringly obvious and is also immersion breaking.

I can't go into any more detail on this because of potential spoilers, but yeah, doesn't look the greatest sometimes in the beginning.

Ultimately, I really enjoyed the game. I know it looks like I had a lot more to say about the negatives of the game, but that's really just me being nit-picky about visual issues for the most part. 60380518.review:
While this game may be short, it is an experience I will never forget (playing through it 3 times does help it stay in the memory). From the aesthetic of the game to the engaging take on turn-based combat this game captivated me enough to play two normal play throughs plus a New Game Plus play through. There are four aspects to the game which I will discuss that my personal recommendation stands on; story and dialogue, the graphics, the soundtrack and the combat. Please note that I will be keeping this review as a personal story of myself with the game, I suggest you look at other reviews for more in-depth details regarding mechanics as you will not find that here. 

Story/Dialogue:
This game is a fairy tale through and through, from the story to the rhyming narration and dialogue. This is arguably the weakest part of the game as I have seen reviews that point out how the constant rhymes can be annoying towards the later end of the game. However for me personally this take on story telling not only drew me into the world, but made me laugh, smile and tear up; providing a charming narrative which I have yet to get tired of. 

The Graphics:
I will not comment much on the graphics of the game as it is clear to see the distinct style that Child of Light offers is one of its draws. It drew me into the game and I have no regrets about my purchase or the requirement of a Ubisoft account (something at the time, I did not have). All I have to say regarding the artwork that this game is, is that it compliments the fairy tale aesthetic of the game and filled me with awe and wonder as I ventured into new areas. 

The Soundtrack:
For anyone considering to purchase this game or even those who don't have an interest in games like this, I suggest you listen to the soundtrack. The beauty of the main theme exemplifies the appeal of the environment and the child like fascination with this remarkable fairy tale. The ambient music encourages you to adventure through the wonderous environments. The frenetic combat and boss music filled me with energy as I sought combat to either further the story or for a way to strengthen my characters. The piano is the key centrepiece of the soundtrack and is enchanting bringing you further into the game and the world it is set in.

The Combat:
While some might be turned off by turned base combat, the way in which Child of Light engages the player through the ability to control the pace of combat adds another level of tactics to what otherwise would be simplistic combat. But this addition removed the monotony of combat and I actively grinded levels in order to experience more of the innovative take on turn based combat. 

As with any game it is not perfect, however, this game not only helped open my eyes to what games could be as well as being a way I could use games to make me feel better in not just a relaxing way, but also an emotionally fulfilling way. I kept this review personal to me because the story of how this game brightened my mood best conveys my recommendation for this game and I am thankful for the creators for making a game that always put a smile on my face.

This game had sat in my wishlist for quite a long time, and so I finally decided to pick it up during the last Autumn sale. It is worth it, more than worth it. I will say even full price is worth it. 

I've had never known that this game is turn-based. I was only interested in it because I like these indie games with beautiful artstyle, music etc... In fact, I almost hate turn-based game. However, I didn't refund Child of Light, because the combat is actually quite good, interesting and very challenging. Easy to get used to but hard to master. Based on the very basic turn-based gameplay, they added it a timeline with a small "cast" line at the end. Each combatant in the field can only start his/her action when they reach the "cast" line, and then they need to go through that line to finally do the action. Each character has their own speed and there are 4 speed types for action: quick, medium, long and very long. Combined together, the time for you to go through that "cast" line will be very quite different depends on your character on the field and his/her action. This is very important because if your character got hit when casting, his/her will be interrupted and pushed back on the timeline. There are 2 ways to prevent this: using defend (action) or unstoppable (either elexir or spell from characters). With this system, you can also cheese your enemies if you hit them during there casting phase to intterrupt them as well, especially with Igniculus, your dear firefly. You can use Igniculus to slow enemies on the timeline or heal your combatants on your field (only one at a time). By using Igniculus, you can prevent enemies from acting and/or allow you to multiple action in a row without worrying about being interrupted. Note that Igniculus has a mana meter and using any of its ability will deplete it. As the fight get longer, you will have less chance to use Igniculus (you can refill that meter as well).
You can change your combatants on your field in your turn without losing it, so u can switch to another character if one yours on the field is being low on health and you can't heal him/her or if you want to focus on enemies weakness that some of your characters can exploit. Talking about weakness, every enemy have their own strength and weakness. However, the game never tell you that so in order to achknowledge them, you have to get in a fight, attack for some turns and then flee (instant, free and 100% success.) Or you can just search for them on the internet :s (I won't judge you for doing it, especially on expert mode which is brutal).
There are oculli (gems) and potions you will find while playing. You can't buy them, so the only way to find them is exploring. open chests and winning fights (they drop randomly at the end of each fight). You can also craft ocullis if you already have some in your inventory. 3 same ocullis in same quality will result in 1 higher tier of that oculli or you can mix 2/3 ocullis together for a unique oculli (again, must be same quality). The best oculli of all is Princess Stone and during my playthrough, I could only craft 2 of them. Oculli have different effects when apply to each slot (there are 3 slots, one oculli when apply to a specific slot will have different effect and diffrent occulis have diffrent effects as well). Based on enemies during your fight, you might want to change your occuli loadout (must flee to do so). This will happen very frequently so you need to get used to it. 

Now, about what bring me into this game. Child of Light has beautiful soundtracks and good story (generic, but good nonetheless). Both of them will start off quite low and only begin to grow into you stronger later on mid game and become very good (music), interesting (story) during late game. The final boss fight music is absolute epic and phenomenal, meanwhile credit music is beautiful and emotional. 
Also one thing I didn't know about this game is that this game use rhyme instead of normal lines, completely. Every single line, dialogue, narrator etc... are rhyme. I'm not a fan of rhyme so at early game this really annoy me, but later on I get used to it. If you like rhyme then considering this aspect because the rhyme in this game is beautiful. 

For an RPG game, of course there will be some sidequests. Fortunately, there are not much in this game and most of them will just reward you will occuli, potion or stardust (a consumable that permently increase a specific stat on whoever you use it on). Note that sidequest doesn't reward you exp. 

If you play this game just for the artstyle, music and story, play on casual mode. Expert mode is no joke. I played 1st playthrough on expert because I didn't expect it to be that hard. Enemies hit like a truck, have tons of health and they also have some very annoying strength/weakness. I mamaged to keep my game on expert but it was literally hell. Every fight is intense and you will have to bring your A-game most of the times. I raged quit during some boss fights as well. But of course, winning a difficult fight is indeed satisfying.

In conclusion, a very good game. 9/10 for me. No bugs/glitches/crash. 

P.s: Fuq you Ubisoft. I exchange your Ubisoft club rewards but they are nowhere to be found in the game. Not in my inventory. Not a big deal but it annoys me.

55014005.review:
Child of Light is a linear story driven puzzle RPG. It's a beautiful game to look at with a fable like art style.
Sometimes I just like to explore a level to see the background scenery with all the little details the developers put in.

Your playable characters all have a unique skill tree and a backstory with a special side mission associated with them, like the loyalty missions of Mass Effect. All your characters receive XP even if they are not fighting, and since each have a unique set of skills, each fill its own niche in a fight. Example: Finn is an elemental mage, useful when enemies share an elemental weakness. Your main character is a balanced magic swordman with anti-dark abilities.

The combat system is based around a timeline, with several mechanics to manipulate and interrupt the advancement speed and executions of the skills. You play with two characters at a time and can swap them at will during the character's turn. The starting position on the timeline is semi random with bonus if you 'ambush' the enemy in the overworld. There is enough variations with enemy weaknesses/timeline that you can't spam the same strategy over and over to quickly finish a fight and you have to think on what to do, especially if you are underleveled for an area. This added spice keep the combat from feeling too repetitive.

Each character has three slots, and the equipment is in the form of crystals called 'oculi' that can be combined to have different effects. Example: a ruby add fire damage as weapon, but fire resistance as defense. I advise looking for the crafting table online and not discover the combinations yourself if you want to get to the highest tier equipment as the highest tier item requires basically all the oculi you can collect in a playthrough to craft.

The story is not particularly unique with many cliche, especially the plot twists. I still enjoyed it because of the unique characters you get to know along the ride. The ending was satisfying for me. It took me about 10h to finish the game and I'm a completionist. You can probably finish the game in 5h if you rush it.

In short, this is a good game if you are looking for a 5h to 10h linear fairy tale story game with beautiful art presentation and unique characters.

GAMEPLAY: 
--- Basic gameplay mechanics involve platforming and flying mixed in with turn-based RPG mechanics. 
--- All movement is in 2D, with your character flying around the areas and encountering monsters or secrets along the way.
--- Controls involve flying and moving your pointer to collect jewels and open chests throughout the areas.  When you touch an enemy, the action shifts into a turn-based RPG system, where you will select commands and manipulate a gauge that controls your party’s turn speed.
--- The main game can be completed in about 20-30 hours (depending on skill and if you decide to 100% everything). 
--- There is a new game plus system if you decide to go through again.
--- Supports either keyboard or controller inputs.  Controls are very responsive.

GRAPHICS: 
--- Looks sharp and runs nicely on my system, which is 5 years old. As usual, visit any game's Steam page to ensure your system can handle it.
--- The art style is reminiscent of a story book or watercolor painting.  Animation can seem a bit stiff in some of the character movements, but nothing too jarring or offputting.
--- Runs buttery smooth with no lag or hiccups whatsoever.  

SOUND:
--- Great symphonic score to accompany the action.  Generally mellow tones for the 2D platforming action, and more dramatic tones for the battle phases.

OTHER NOTES:
--- A UPlay account must be created and active while playing this game.
--- Certain DLC items can be unlocked by earning UPlay coins, which are acquired after performing certain achievements
--- One achievement appears to be dead (the one you get for trading stones with a friend online; the online system is now gone).  Keep this in mind if you’re an achievement hunter.

FINAL VERDICT
--- I found this to be a lot fun for what it was. I picked it up for less than $5, and couldn't be happier with my purchase. 
--- I went through the game twice, but don’t think I’d return again anytime soon (unless the dead achievement is somehow obtainable one day).   
--- Recommended for those folks who love platformers and classic JRPGs.
