Unfortunately, I can't recommend this game. From the reviews a few years ago, I had thought this might be a universally appreciated game, an aesthetic and gameplay experience that was moving and uplifting. But as I'm playing it, it definitely feels uneven in what it delivers. More importantly, it's definitely oriented toward a younger demographic than I expected. I would have adored this game when I was thirteen, I think. (No slam, of course---I love deeply the games I played when I was that age.) 

From the get-go, there are a number of underwhelming elements. The writing, in particular, is distractingly poor. There's a fun conceit that everyone speaks in couplets and the occasional quatrains, which should be great---only the poetry is really low-quality. There's more to poetry (even whimsical poetry!) than rhyming! I'm really, really tired of developers getting that the art should be phenomenal, and then treating the writing and elegance of story-presentation as an afterthought. It's like wearing a dress and then going out in sneakers. 

"If you don't let me pass this day / I will turn you into clay!"  would be endearing if at least *some* of the poetry by the narrator or wise characters has *some* understanding of meter or beautiful phrasing. But it's ALL just awkward prose with two rhyming sentences in a row. Oof.

Then the story itself is not great. For some reason, there's an over-story about 1895 Austria, which, before I bought the game, I was like "hey, cool! That's interesting." But in fact, it's not integrated into the story or art in any way. There's no sprinkled German words or names, the fantasy art doesn't seem particularly Austrian-inspired. Instead, it creates a lot of distance between the world Aurora is trying to return to, and the one she is in. This is one of those inelegant joints that prevents this game from feeling like a completely smooth package.

Combat was okay, although also not quite right. For the first five hours, even on the hardest difficulty, I could win every battle almost immediately by surprise attacking and then mass striking them. The bigger disappointment was the lack of RPG elements: There's no meaningful choices for your characters. You level up a 'branch' that orients your stats toward strength or magic or defense, but doesn't really change your gameplay or unlock new skills. (One branch unlocks: Strike I, Strike II, Strike II (all), Strike III. Boring!) Passive skills are meaningless, like one that gives a measly 10% chance of counterattack. It's one of those games that *has* crafting, inventories, skillpoint trees, but for all intents and purposes isn't really an RPG. In the end, combat always felt a bit scrunched, and I didn't quite get a sense of what the combat wanted to be.

The art was good, and the main theme is beautiful. However, Aurora herself is kind of dreary and obtuse. I did enjoy, though, that the game gave up on platforming after the first hour -- an unexpected breath of fresh air from the Metroidvania ability-drip for map exploration.

And then, of course, the technical things. My cheap laptop (which can play Total War: Warhammer on low just fine) could only play this game on 800x600 resolution. I buy these games in part because my computer can run them, and it was dissappointing the lack of optimization or graphical options. And then, of course, you have to install a bunch of Ubisoft junk in order to play this of UPlay -- not something I feel enraged by, by annoying, nonetheless.

So, in the end, if you're looking for one of this indie gems, this probably isn't it: This is dependent on age, or love of artistic concept. Which is fine! However, if you're looking for a gentle, beautiful, relaxing, whimsical, children's-story-esque platformer, give Trine 2 a try first.

52183814.review:
This might be THE most beautiful and charming game I've ever played. It should be considered as "a work of art", rather than just a game. This game does so many things right that it's hard to find a place to start talking about it.

Child Of Light takes place in a beautiful, watercolored looking world where characters speak in rhymes(except one, but I'll get to that). It is a coming of age story that has a fairy tale feeling all around it, with our main character Aurora pulling a sword from a pedestal within the first minutes of the game. Even though it looks like it's a platformer at the beginning, platforming aspects soon disappear and a 10 hour long RPG journey begins.

The characters are charming, lovable and, most of the time, adorable. Their personalities and banters are a joy to witness. My favorite was easily Rubella, who always failed to speak in rhymes. It usually infuriated other characters, who tried to fix her. There are many playable characters filling different roles such as tank, healer, physical dps, magical dps, buffing/debuffing etc. You can change characters on a whim during fights. The combat system is ATB, with a twist. As your character's icon gets to a spot on ATB bar, you give them a command. If they are attacked before they execute that command, it is canceled and they are put back on the bar. You can also use your cursor to slow down enemies and heal your allies during combat, which makes it very interactive and never boring. It is an easy game however, even on hard mode I scarcely felt in danger. 

Soundtrack is among the finest I've had the pleasure of listening. Most of the time, music in games can't catch my attention, and I have to listen to them afterwards to appreciate them. But even on the title screen, this game's soundtrack captured me and never let go. It creates a magical atmosphere as it is accompanied by gorgeous graphics. Aurora's hair is animated so wonderfully that you can just stand there and watch it as a beatiful piece of music plays in the background. Character sprites are as good as the world itself, which is quite a feat.

I can talk about this game for hours and still can't express how dazzling and fascinating it is. I just hope I can convince you to give it a shot as it is totally worth every cent you can spend on it. It saddens me so much that we will never see a sequel(real or spiritual) to this hidden gem. But it might not be the last time we see Aurora, as her theme was heard in another game's trailer by the time this review was written. I just hope future yields more Child of Light content for all of us to enjoy.

"Aurora, what is love known by?"
"When it hurts to say goodbye."

You are Aurora, a child princess who, after contracting an illness, awaken in a mysterious land. With nothing but a talkative firefly to guide you, you are left to soar through the hauntingly beautiful landscape to seek answers about who you were and what you had left behind.

It is hard for me to put into words what Child of Light means to me or what affect it had on me while I was traversing through Lemuria as Aurora. I felt like I was floating through a water-coloured dreamscape, which, if I wasn't careful was as dangerous as it was enchanting. The melodies were poignant and struck a chord even with someone as heartless as myself. It was clear Aurora was a lost child, but as she explored, the music gave way to a tune of hope as she found allies to alleviate the loneliness.

Child of Light has fairytale elements, what with the whimsical rhyming between the characters and narrator and the colourful cast who can tag along, should you choose to help them.

It offers a turn based combat system, with the ability to knock back or interrupt attacks. This requires careful planning of turns, where you consider the risks of pulling off a flashy move, if say the enemy has a chance to go before you and cancel out the attack altogether! It is reminiscent of Grandia 2 and for me, makes the combat highly enjoyable. And if you are into the ol' skill trees, the also game boasts an expansive array of skill options for the cast.

My parting words to you all? If you have ever woken up from a dream and longed to return, feeling as though you didn't have enough time to explore the mysterious make-believe world. This is the game for you. Step in, take Aurora's hand and guide her through to wakefulness.

49885101.review:
Imagine a fairy tale.
The beautiful flowing music, the sometimes awkward, sometimes wonderful rhymes and elder way to express speech.
A beautiful world that seems to have been born out of a of work from Yoshitaka Amano, reimagined by Thomas Rollus, composed to a play by the Cirque de Soleil.
Princess Aurora wanders through that water colored dream to become the Queen that she is destined to be.
That's the core of Child of Light.

It was a wondrous journey with lots of memorable moments.
There are quite a few similar metroidvania-esque games that offer that sense of exploring a beautiful world.
I played the casual way to sweeten my evenings, I'm here to indulge in a fairy tail, not to find a challenge.
Of course there's something dark to fight and a world to save with light.

The game-play works really well, and just goes along lovingly.
It's not the high point of the game, but it carries it's weight.
It brings back the nostalgia when Final Fantasy was on more traditional ways.
Those Turn-based, time-restricted (alas Active Time Battle) kind of battle mechanics just work really well.
There is no 'analysis' of foes, but over time you learn to read the colors properly.
It's well-crafted and solid, so it makes you feel right at home.
It even brings in a sweet little mechanic that lets you influence the flow of time to some degree.
Even better, it ties in neatly with the plot.

After 16 hours, my journey with Aurora has com to a close.
I'll wander around in NG+ for a while and enjoy revisiting that story.
After all that said it might be quite clear that I'm gonna recommend that game.
Of course I do. If the things I describe pique your interest, it should be a blast.

ps. There are of course a few negative things.

7/10: Child of Light is a very pretty, dreamlike game that is best for those looking for a low intensity 2D experience and turn-based combat featuring a sword-wielding fairy princess. 

Child of Light feels like playing through a storybook combination of The Wizard of Oz and Journey to the West. Aurora is a young princess in Austria during the late 1800's who finds herself banished to the mythical realm of Lemuria. To return home, she must traverse this surreal place and help the many beings that have been affected by the Evil Queen. In return, they join her party and lend Aurora their strength on her mission to return home. 

Stylistically, the game is very nice both visually and musically. Aurora's flowing red hair stands out against the illustrated backgrounds and characters, and the musical score is a mellow combination of string and piano that accentuates the lullaby feeling surrounding the story. This is only compounded by the fact that (almost) every character speaks in rhyme, as well as the generally floaty nature of the movement in the game.

Mechanically, the game is neither especially complex nor overly simple. The combat is turn-based, but the active party only has 2 slots so the variety of choices available at a given moment feel a bit lower than the typical 3-member setup. This is combined with an initiative timeline where players can interrupt enemies if they strike them just as they are preparing to attack, and vice versa. Each character as well as Aurora has 3 paths of skills to improve on, but these paths don't really intertwine with each other so the process of leveling becomes very straightforward as you try to max out one path to make sure each character is at least focused and useful, so every character has only a handful of skills they ever need to use. 

Rather than equipping weapons and armor, every character has 3 slots for gems called Oculi. Combining 3 Oculi of the same color makes an Oculi of a higher level, while combining 2 Oculi of different colors creates a different kind of Oculi. Since the effectiveness of the Oculi change depending on their type and what slot they are in, experimenting with the different types of Oculi and figuring out which ones most fit your play style provides much of the games depth and long term strategy.

Grinding is easy, since you can easily blind enemies with Igniculus' flare and sneak up on them to initiate an ambush. Most of the time combat comes down to whether physical combat is good enough to handle things or if it's necessary to bring out one of the few characters with decent magic attacks to exploit specific vulnerabilities before settling into the groove of interrupting enemies and slowing them down using Igniculus' light. While things are noticeably tougher on Hard than on Normal, even then Child of Light is rarely frustrating or overwhelming. 

Overall, Child of Light is a 2D RPG with a clear focus on storybook style and a dreamlike story. Good for a dozen hours of exploratory play and simple turn-based combat, and recommended for anyone who enjoys a good lullaby and can get over the protagonist being a fairy princess.

Child of Light can be best described as a mix of a platformer with a jrpg. You play Aurora, a young girl who falls ill and wakes up in dark kingdom of Lemuria, which she needs to free from evil Queen of Night, Umbra. You travel first by jumping and then flying, while solving puzzles with use of your elemental friend Igniculus, a helpful little guy that is also your mouse icon and whom you can use to make light, blinding enemies so Aurora can pass them, cast shadows on objects, open floating boxes and activate mechanisms through mirrors.

 In combat, you have a modified turn-based fight with two members of your party facing up to three enemies. The order is dedicated by how yor characters move on the timeline and you can use Igniculus to slow enemies down. Each action you choose takes time to execute so if you're not careful enemy might get a hit on your characters while you're executing an attack, interrupting it and pushing your character back on the timeline. There is an extra number of mechanics you need to keep an eye on, including elemental resistance and vulnerabilities based on what crystals you equip to characters or which enemies will counterattack if you interrupt them using magic, physical force or both. The fights can be challenging even on easy difficulty if you are not careful. There is a number of ways to make them less challenging in late parts of the game, with characters like Ógenus -a party tank who attracts enemies to himself - or Norah and Genovefa's abilities to paralyze your enemies. However, while they might become a necessity on the harder difficulty, they can make the game too easy on the lower and one of the game's flaws is lack of a middle difficulty level. You either play it as a casual player like me, who wants to enjoy the story and atmosphere more than battles or as a hardcore gamer for whom it's not fun unless every charming party member gets punched to the bring of their life by each encounter. A middle ground would be much welcome for players who wish for best of both worlds and find hard mode to suck as much fun out of the game as they do think easy mode is too easy in late stage.

The cast of characters is incredibly charming. Aurora is a brave little girl with a big heart who rather realistically just wants to go home to her father and Igniculus being her loyal sidekick. On their travels, they get aided by a number of characters that show quite a lot of awareness of typical rpg archetype and lack of fear towards playing with them on the creator's side. Finn, both a wizard and local equivalent of a dwarf is, despite his beard, a scared teenager who needs moral support. While Robert, the resident archer is as far removed from typical rpg take on the character as possible, not only being a giant bipedal mouse but also a shrewd businessman whose main motivation turns out to be love. It's just two examples out of a rich and very sympathetic cast. The creators know their fantasy and know how to deliver old tropes and archetypes in a way that we either find interesting or can accept. Most genre savvy players would figure Umbra's identity as far as chapter one but the reveal is played as twist for the main character, not for the players, coming off as just an extra to a twist people were less likely to see coming.  And even including the antagonists I need to say that at no point have I found any character annoying. 

It might be in part because the game's entire story is delivered in rhyme, giving it very charming, kid-friendly feel. It fits seamlessly with stunning graphics of this imaginative, fantastic world that evoke style of a children's book and a climactic soundtrack that, while limited is full of enchanting piano and violin parts as well as epic battle themes (complete with chanting chorus for boss battles) that never grow tiresome no matter how much you hear the same track. It really feels like a fairy tale the story is obviously inspired by and on easier difficulties I would recommend it to any gamer with kids - it has good morals and everything to get a kid fascinated as a good fairy tale would and you can easily play together, with one of you controlling Aurora and the other controlling Igniculus.

The only other flaw the game has is the post-ending gameplay. You can continue roaming the world after finishing the game, which feels out of place. It clashes with the effort put to make the game feel like a storybook with a definite end and even undermines it somehow. Child of Light is a focused story that does not offer much in a way of post-game content. Unless you didn't neglect some sidequests or need to collect all the confessions - pieces of lore floating around on sheets of paper in the wind - there is really nothing to do. Combat at this point becomes too easy, as you are so powerful you can kill all enemies in many areas with single strike and leveling your characters is sooner than latter gonna turn into a grind. The only appeal of playing after finishing the story for me is to appreciate the beautiful world and let it become your soothing, feel-good game to relax. It feels like Ubisoft tacked it on the last minute out of, I don't know fear otherwise people might say they made an indie game and an actual story and not a "Triple A experience"?

Nonetheless, Child of Light is a game with amazing atmosphere, wonderful style, charming characters and story that makes you feel like a kid tucked in your bed when mom comes to read you before sleep, but might also be a challenging experience for veteran players. Strongly recommended.

This game has two main parts to it... it's a bit of a 2d puzzle platformer / metroidvania lite and a bit of a turn-based rpg, with an interruptable active timer like Grandia or Trails in the Sky.

Both parts of the game are mediocre at best.

The 2d puzzle platforming portion of the game doesn't go from simple to complex but maintains the same level of simplicity the whole game.  If you want a good puzzle platformer you're better off playing a castlevania game, a metroid game, ori and the blind forest, and so on.

As a turn-based RPG, the game has a handful of the usual things you would expect -- elemental weaknesses and strengths, spellcasting and interruptions, haste and slowing turn order, gemming and gear customization and so on -- but It doesn't do anything particularly new or interesting with those mechanics.  And I think it's hampered by having only 2 slots for characters in combat at once.  You can swap party members instantly on your turn with the swapped-in character immediately getting their turn.  So you can get use out of your different characters... but there are so many characters with overlapping abilities I never found the need to use each and every character.  And mroe to the point, having only 2 slots means you're basically competing to get 2 turns while your enemy often gets 3, which does add some challenge but feels cheap in doing so.

Story-wise and art-wise, I give the game props for successfully feeling like you're inside a children's fairy tale, with rhyming or near-rhyming dialogue (for most of the game) and watercolor backgrounds.  I will complain that the sprite for the main heroine is rather on the ugly side (kind of super-deformed with a big head)... well, actually all the sprites are pretty lackluster, but the backgrounds are beautiful, and the character profiles in the dialogue windows are pretty, though perhaps not especially expressive.  As for the characters themselves, it's a really short game with a whole lot of characters, so none of them get a whole lot of time.  Sidequests will give you a bit more, and you get some banal after-battle interactions between your previous characters and a new character after picking him up.  I think it would have been better, given the length of the game, to have fewer characters, or to have choices between which character to take, and branching dialogue paths based on which characters you got (like what Square did in secret of mana 2, for instance).

Let me also address the multiplayer mode of this game.  You can have a second player handle the firefly for you if you want, but mostly the game is setup in such a way that you're only ever using the character or the firefly at any given moment, and there's never a need to use both simultaneously.  You can slow enemies during the rpg battle phase of the game by sparking the firefly on them, and this is practically a necessity for bossfights with especially speedy enemies, but the timebar freezes while you select actions for your characters.  So you are either using the firefly or you're selection options, not both simultaneously.  Likewise in the puzzle platforming parts of the game, you are either solving a light puzzle with the firefly, hitting a switch with the firefly, or navigating the screen with your heroine.... there really aren't any moments where you need the character and the firefly each doing something independently.

So all that said, I wouldn't recommend this game highly.  Maybe if you really like games of this type and have already beaten the really good ones, and this is on sale.... but otherwise, meh.  There are way better games out there.

45718399.review:
[b]Name[/b] - Child of Light

[b]Game Completion[/b] - Completed

[b]Story - 9 out of 10[/b]
Child of Light is about a young princess named Aurora who wakes up in the fairytale land of Lemuria. She meets a firefly named Igniculus, who guides her through the game and stays by her side, teaching her how to fight and so on. She learns about the Queen of Light becoming missing from this world, and how darkness has risen, while being shown that her only way out is to restore the light to Lemuria.

Through her journey she meets a wide variety of colourful characters who are absolutely blooming with personality as she ventures to save the light. The story has a very charming tone when it comes to progressing and areas, it's amazing at conveying the mood and creating memorable areas, characters, and music. 

[b]Characters -  7 out of 10[/b]
The characters you meet over the course of playing Child of Light are filled with lovable and unique personalities galore. Jesters and rhymes, (or at least trying their best to.), odd friends, mice, and everything nice! The majority of the characters in Child of Light are very memorable designs, though some came up a bit shoddy at parts, lacking development or that little 'oomph' you might need to get a character to hit perfect. But overall, the characters in this game were lovely as can be.

[b]Gameplay - 7 out of 10[/b]
The gameplay of Child of Light is a platformer mixed in with a time-based RPG (Where characters take their turns after a certain build-up bar has passed, for example.) The combat in this game is very enjoyable and smooth, with few bad designs here and there. Though not every game is perfect, almost all of the unique bosses and enemies were pleasant and satisfying to fight.

The exploration in the platformer segments of the game was usually enjoyable, though some segments came up shy, where there were either minor movement bugs, or places that were just far too frustrating to traverse through. Though overall, I enjoyed Child of Light's combat much more than most of the recent RPGs.

[b]Content - 10 out of 10[/b]
The game might not be huge (I'd say it takes around 13 hours or so to do everything) but it's an amazing experience to play through. The amount of hidden little things you might find, on top of the beautiful art style, make you want to always be looking around once more! There is a lengthy story and lots of quests to do, areas to explore and enemies to encounter.

Majority you'll do in this game will be related to the main story, so you likely aren't going to miss much when playing through. I think every area in this game is worth admiring, every line of dialogue is beautifully written, and the battling and adventure feels satisfying.

[b]Post Game/Replayability - 8 out of 10[/b]
This game is definitely one I'd play through many times over after a long break. This game is definitely a memorable one, and a worthwhile experience even if you know how the story goes. I've personally played through it thrice on console, and once on Steam. With such charming gameplay and designs, it's hard not to want to re-admire Child of Light a second, or even third time. Child of Light doesn't exactly contain post-game content, due to almost everything being done in the normal game.

[b]Overall - 9 of 10[/b]
Child of Light gets a fantastic rating from me, with almost every part of the game being a masterpiece and unique, it's hard not to almost give is a 10/10. I believe that, despite this game being several years old, still lives up to the current games of the genre as well, and is definitely a suggested pick-up for RPG lovers! The game isn't extremely difficult either, so it's fairly easy to casually enjoy as well.

44229873.review:
Child Of Light is a RPG, with turn-based combat element. Player plays as Aurora, who wakes up in a dream-like island called Lemuria. After following sequence of events, Aurora gains the ability to fly, allowing her to further explore the world in search of collectibles scattered across the island and to save Lemuria from darkness.

Together with Igniculus (cursor), Aurora can choose fight (on contact with) or flee away (using Igniculus’ glow to blind) from the dark creatures roaming around the island. Aurora will be able to recruit NPCs into her party to further aid her in combat. Successful combat will allow Aurora and her party members to gain experience and level up. Each ally, Aurora and her party members, have their own unique skill tree, ranging from elemental to supportive to status inflicting abilities. Crafting system also allows Aurora and her party to gain better passive stats and elemental abilities.

Story is very well conveyed through its water painting art, voiceover narration, pleasing audio, and rhyming dialogue between the characters. It feels very relaxing to just float around the land getting lost and voluntarily get ambushed by the dark creatures. However, the turn-based combat system might take some time for players to get used to and could be frustrating to deal with.

I’ve played the game in casual mode and health resources are infinite, but spawns at a slow rate, which means that I do not have to worry much about health when it comes to combat. However, decision making during the turn-based combat is still crucial as I do not want to take damage or prolong my battle unnecessarily. During the turn-based combat, Igniculus can assist Aurora and her party members by healing an ally, or by slowing an enemy down, making the enemy attack at a slower pace while Aurora gains the advantage to intercept her enemies’ attack. Decision making is still required as Igniculus’ glow is limited and has to be used sparingly and at the right moment.

There is also replay value in the New Game Plus mode after completing the main game. This is for players to collect missing collectibles for achievements and/or to build stronger party members through leveling and crafting. Game is recommended for those who wants to immerse themselves in a casual RPG driven by a simple princess story.

Do take note that in order to play this game, Uplay application and account is required. Uplay download will be prompted if player does not have the Uplay application upon opening the game through steam.

This game was a mixed bag for me. Here were a couple of things I really loved:
-The battle system (the timing/interrupting enemies' attacks was usually very fun)
-The art style, of course. Beautiful watercolors everywhere you look!
-Quick "cutscenes" with interactions between new party members as you acquire them. Because these were SHORT (just a few seconds each, really) I could enjoy them without them destroying the flow of my gameplay. Tales of Symphonia could have learned something here.

On the art style--it was beautiful, but to echo a review from somewhere else (Kotaku?), I wish those beautiful big open areas had more stuff to see or interact with in them besides enemies. They felt kind of empty. Even though the flying in this game is fun, once I moved more quickly I think I stopped soaking in the areas the same way I did at the beginning or in a game like, say, Hollow Knight.

Stuff I wasn't a fan of:
-Overly simplistic plot. Well, actually the plot isn't too bad, but the main issue is that it is made to sound fairly silly because of...
-EVERYTHING WRITTEN IN VERSE. The intent was to give this the sound of an old-fashioned fable or fairytale, but unfortunately some of the poems are so bad, or the rhymes so predictable, that the game began to take on the spirit of Dr. Seuss. Even in Alice and Wonderland (with some lovely silly poetry), the reason why Tweedle Dee's rhymes work is because they're counterbalanced against someone who doesn't speak that way (Alice). It would have been great if some characters spoke in verse (e.g. Rubella, the trader village) but not everyone. When you get those "secret notes" written in regular prose, it's like a breath of fresh air: "Ah, at least ONE character in this game [even though I never get to see them] doesn't sound pretentious or silly!"

Beautiful art style with a captivating storyline and good rock, paper, scissors style conflicts.

Child of Light has me enjoying the story of a little princess trying to get back home, meeting and making friends with strangers and helping solve riddles and conflicts on the way, undergoing a personal growth. The characters in this game are wonderfully illustrated and animated, with dynamic personalities. 

When fighting the conflicts in this game, they've done a great job to make the enemies balanced and a new challenge every time, where you get involved in learning which type of moves work well on which type of enemies. I like how although the rules are very rock, paper, scissors style, the creaters of Child of Light have managed to create more types than the classic three, and involve other mechanics in the damage calculation as well (does the enemy have magic resistance, or physical attack resistance, or can you only attack them from range?). These are all creative ways to add depth to an otherwise static fighting style, so good job done there.

Outside of the regular storyline, the game keeps you working on your Occuli as well (little gems you find around the world that you can collect and combine) so that you can add buffs to your character or your attack in game. The Occuli are quite common to find, but to create the top tier Occuli will take you a while, making the game not a quick and easy two hour interactive story. 

You can usually choose to take a fight or avoid it, but the character levelling system motivates you to take new fights all the time so you can work towards learning a new move in the development tree or permanent buffs for your character. The moves can be upgraded, as can every other stat on your character. There is a variety of characters you can play with as well, each one with their own strengths and weaknesses.


All in all, Child of Light is a beautifully illustrated and animated game with a captivating storyline and great dynamic character arcs. I've had a wonderful time playing it and I fully recommend it to anyone looking for an enjoyable visually pleasing story to play through.

I hope this review helps you decide whether it's for you or not and if you do get it, have fun! :)

ps.
If you love poetry, then you'll love this, as almost every bit of story is written as poetry, and even some breaking of the fourth wall when some characters don't understand how to rhyme, it's beautiful.

Awesome turn-based battle system that requires some pretty solid strategy if you want to beat the whole game. I really enjoyed this game and I would play through it more if it let me play the way I want to. Short enough for a casual player, but if you want to fully enjoy the New Game+ you might be disappointed.

I played through one time in about 15h doing all side quests but decided that I didn't want to spend the time on NG+.

[b]GOOD![/b]

Battle system is absolutely solid. A lot of turn-based games might as well be automated. Not here. On Expert mode I was constantly switching characters, changing my elemental damage, micro managing resources, and still died a couple times.

There are two mechanics that make the combat great. First, you have a "turn bar" that's exactly like Chrono Trigger's except after you pick a move it has a Cast Time. If you or the enemy are hit during the Cast Time you lose your turn. The classic method of focus firing is no longer valid. Even against bosses you'll need to interrupt their supers while managing adds and not losing turns yourself.

The second thing is the light system. Your mouse controls your light which can slow one enemy's turn bar. This compounds with the interrupt mechanic, but can also be used as a heal. You are constantly deciding whether the slow or the heal are more important. Very fun.

Instead of gear you have the Oculi system. It's basically Diablo 2's gems but more effective, more effects than just elemental damage and resist, and you can freely unsocket out of battle. I really liked managing my Oculi gems and being able to swap them based on the setting, although the final boss kind of spits in your face by not allowing you to swap before battle.

[b]Okay.[/b]

Skill trees are pretty standard. Each character gets three and you work toward capstones. You can complete almost 2 full trees by the end of your first playthrough.

The story didn't really grab me and the rhyming dialogue draws out what is already a very talky game.

[b]Really bad![/b]

NOTHING is skippable. Eventually you get the story, dad is dying need to go home, evil lady bad. Everything else is filler and only half the text can even be sped up and none can be skipped. Characters will incessantly banter between battles preventing you from managing your skill trees. I was fine with it for one playthrough and really wanted to do NG+ so I could get the highest level Oculi gems but the second I found out I couldn't skip anything I just quit.

When will devs learn? We know you worked hard on your story but for god's sake if we've ALREADY PLAYED THE GAME let us skip it!

Oh, also there's a subtle thing that causes your cursor to move on its own sometimes (in combat). Whatever idiot programmed that thought it was cute should be dragged behind a truck. I thought it was my mouse and cleaned it twice before I realized the little light bulb cursor character was moving on his own.

If you like turn-based RPGs you'll want to play this one. It has a nice story for kids and I would gladly do another playthrough if I could just play the game instead of watching hours of custscenes and dialogue again.

39831102.review:
Child of Light es un juego de plataformas y rol ambientado en un mundo mágico con inspiración en múltiples elementos de fantasía, que terminan otorgándole un aspecto Disney al conjunto, así como de fábula clásica.

Mediante batallas con sistema de turnos extraído directamente de los títulos rpg y sencillos elementos de plataformas y exploración en 2D tendremos que recorrer la bella tierra de Lemuria durante unas 12-15 horas.

 Encarnamos a Aurora, una niña que tras desaparecer de su castillo, tendrá la doble tarea de salvar a su padre, así como de recuperar el sol, las estrellas y la luna para salvar Lemuria. Narrada a través de unos muy originales diálogos, ya que intencionadamente riman todas las frases a modo de poesía, la historia no es demasiado interesante. Llena de los típicos clichés de luz salvadora en oposición a la malvada oscuridad, la trama se desarrolla a buen ritmo, pero nunca generando un gran interés, salvo algunas pequeñas revelaciones. Conoceremos diferentes y variadas regiones en Lemuria, donde nos encontraremos con variopintos personajes, algunos de los cuales se unirán a nuestra misión, siendo controlables durante las batallas. Destaca la evolución que iremos apreciando en Aurora a medida que avanza la aventura, desde una débil e insegura niña hasta una joven poderosa y con gran confianza en sí misma.

El juego se desarrolla en scroll lateral pudiendo desplazarnos libremente por los escenarios, ya que nuestra protagonista adquiere la capacidad de volar en los primeros compases de la aventura. Una de las características más originales del juego es que con el stick derecho podremos controlar el movimiento también libre de ignículus, un ente que nos sirve a modo de linterna viviente, para activar algunos interruptores, curarnos, recoger tesoros o para distraer a los enemigos. De hecho el juego proporciona la posibilidad de que un 2º jugador se una y sea el encargado de controlar a ignículus, ya que durante las batallas también puede participar apoyando a nuestros guerreros y frenando a los enemigos.

Una parte importante de las mecánicas jugables es la superación de los escenarios en sí mismos, ya que contienen pequeños desafíos plataformeros. Desde ráfagas de viento, pinchos y compuertas que obstaculizan nuestro paso hasta lava, rayos y gases tóxicos que nos bajarán la barra de vida rápidamente. En cualquier caso es bastante sencillo encontrar el camino a seguir y la superación de estas trampas, ya que siempre podemos curarnos fácilmente, sea gracias a ignículus, algunos arbustos iluminados o tirando de las numerosas pociones que acumularemos. Habrá pequeñas pruebas donde tendremos que depositar cajas sobre interruptores para levantar compuertas o pequeños puzzles donde tendremos que jugar con la proyección de sombras que genera nuestro amigo ignículus según su posición espacial y los objetos que ilumine. Estos desafíos aportan variedad al título, aunque no son muchos y son demasiado sencillos de resolver, resultando un mero pasatiempo y no demasiado inspirados. Algunos de estos desafíos se encuentran en rutas opcionales que nos llevan a obtener alguna recompensa, como potenciadores o coleccionables.
El juego contiene también 11 tareas secundarias que nos encomendarán algunos habitantes de Lemuria. La mayoría consisten en localizar algún objeto concreto y entregárselo a la persona adecuada, eliminar ciertos enemigos o alcanzar alguna zona oculta.
Los enemigos siempre se encuentran a la vista en los escenarios, por lo que podremos sortearlos si no nos apetece entrar en batalla, así como también podemos intentar sorprenderlos por detrás para comenzar con ventaja el combate. Hay buena variedad de enemigos, tanto en su apariencia como en su comportamiento en batalla y vulnerabilidades. Algunos serán más resistentes a los ataques físicos, otros vulnerables al agua, otros más centrados en apoyar al resto de enemigos, etc. Lo común en juegos de rol clásico.
Las batallas son combates por turnos muy simplificados. Podemos manejar a dos aliados a la vez, mientras que podemos enfrentarnos hasta a tres enemigos simultáneamente. Podemos ejecutar diferentes tipos de ataques, algunas habilidades que iremos aprendiendo y mejorando, hechizos, usar objetos de apoyo o de desgaste para los enemigos, cambiar de guerreros o defendernos. Un medidor a modo de barra se va rellenando según la velocidad de cada personaje hasta que nos permite seleccionar el siguiente comando y a medida que se rellena la última parte de la barra se ejecuta dicha acción. Para los enemigos funciona de igual manera. Las batallas suelen ser bastante fáciles, y la mayor estrategia radica en averiguar a qué elemento es vulnerable cada enemigo y en tratar de interrumpir las acciones de nuestros enemigos, lo que se consigue atacándoles justo antes de que se llene su barra de acción. También tratar de que los enemigos no interrumpan nuestras acciones. Solo algunos jefes finales nos harán utilizar hechizos de apoyo así como objetos curativos, teniendo que estar más concentrados en el combate para medir bien nuestros pasos. Estos jefes suponen retos interesantes, además de que tienen diseños curiosos y variados.
Todos los personajes irán ganando experiencia, subiendo de nivel y mejorando sus atributos, así como adquiriendo puntos que desbloquean nuevas habilidades y mejoras en un árbol de desarrollo particular de cada uno. Cada personaje tiene sus fortalezas, debilidades y habilidades especiales, aunque no está muy conseguida la utilización de un aliado concreto con cada tipo enemigo. En general Aurora es el personaje más versátil y eficiente de todos.

Los diálogos son muy simples, y es que con la intención de crear versos con cada frase, resulta complicado poder trazar conversaciones interesantes así. De forma particular me resultó bastante cansino leer todos estos diálogos a modo de poesía interminable. Al principio resulta gracioso y muy original, pero a la larga creo que no está totalmente conseguido y puede terminar desesperando a más de uno.

El apartado artístico es la principal fortaleza de Child of Light, creando hermosas estampas en todos los niveles, pareciendo en ocasiones un cuadro en movimiento. El diseño de escenarios está muy mimado y detallado artísticamente, pero también desde el punto de vista jugable. La mayoría de escenarios ofrecen mucha verticalidad, lo que hace de la exploración algo divertido y profundo, encontrando varios caminos, cuevas escondidas y tesoros ocultos.
Otro punto fuerte destacable es la BSO, con unas piezas musicales muy trabajadas que suenan estupendamente en combinación con la belleza de los escenarios. Hay buena variedad de ellas, más trágicas, alegres o emocionantes según los escenarios y los acontecimientos de la historia.

En general Child of Light es un buen juego de plataformas y rol, muy ligero en contenidos y mecánicas jugables, lo que hace que pueda ser jugado por todo tipo de jugadores. Peca de ser excesivamente fácil y simple, al no profundizar mucho ni en su vertiente plataformera ni en los combates. No encontraremos un verdadero reto de ningún tipo y es relativamente sencillo pasarse el juego sin morir ni una vez o un par de veces a lo sumo.
Con un gran apartado artístico, un dedicado trabajo a la hora de crear poesía de cada diálogo y una BSO que no deja indiferente, el juego derrocha personalidad, resultando una mezcla de estilos no muy vista hasta el momento de su salida en el mercado. Una historia demasiado básica, llena de estereotipos poco originales y personajes muy diferentes entre sí, pero nada memorables y bastante predecibles. Se hubiera agradecido mayor variedad en las habilidades plataformeras o en los desafíos y puzzles, pero en cualquier caso el juego no decepciona y cumple ofreciendo un bonito cuento de superación y maduración.

39312749.review:
Child of Light is a strange game that lets you play as a fairy tale princess on her quest to overcome the darkness that has befallen both the real world and the land of Lemuria, apparently a place little princesses go when they die. There's a backdrop of an eerie darkness that pervades the feel and tone of the game but it never outdoes the absolute delight and beauty of the amazing and varied environments. 

The game itself mostly playes like a side-scroller but without any platforming challenges. Most of your time is spent exploring the different landscapes of lemuria and leveling up your party in JRPG active time battles similar to those found in the Grandia series. I would go as far as to call this system a callback to Grandia because every action you take and every status ailments that happen during battle affect just how far or how behind you are in a set timeline. Once you reach the end of that timeline you'll be prompted to take any action you desire and the same goes for your enemies. It's a very amusing system that puts player agency front and center even though towards the end of the game it starts to show its relative shallowness.

You can level up your characters using gathered experience points. There isn't much to write home about it though. There aren't that many exciting upgrades and most of them are simply buffs to your HP, MP or speed in the battles.

Secondly, the game's writers probably can't write a decent story if their life depended on it. New characters join your party left and right but there is no noteworthy development of the plot or their motivations. Everything plays out just as you'd expect and you can see the single twist from a mile coming. On top of that, the already barebones story is told all through rhymes; and boy do most of those suck pretty bad and serve more as a detriment to the story than helping it feel any more authentic. There's some kind of meta story going on behind the curtains of the fairytale but they're only found in secret notes you find floating around and don't really add to the story one bit. 

Thirdly, the sound design and music here are masterclass. I loved listening to the title track and ending music as well as everything offered in between. There are even awesome little touches inside the menus. Serious kudos to the sound staff involved. 

I don't need to go on about the aesthetics of the game because they are probably some of the most beautiful sights and sounds you'll experience all year. It all looks like a moving watercolor painting and I couldn't get enough of all the gorgeous sights all over Lemuria.

The game takes around 12-15 hours to fully complete (counting side-quests) depending on your pace. Even though the story and the rhyming gimmick are probably the weakest parts of the game, I was thoroughly satisfied with the battles and the overall beauty on offer here. You can choose to play on a more difficult setting but it simply drags out the battles for too long and the need for level grinding is simply not worth the effort imo.

[EDIT] It's no wonder I forgot to mention the most boring and unnecessary part of the gameplay: The Oculi crafting system. You basically find different colored stones (Oculi) with various sizes from chests and quests and you can craft them into bigger ones by combining them using a crafting menu. They give your attack, defence and magic different boosts or add elemental damage. The crafting system however is simply consisted of constantly pressing A to combine stones one by one and it gets tiring really fast.

The Ubiart game engine and its games have not disappointed me with a single title yet and this is up there with the best of them. You just need to go in with a light heart and you'll get your time and money's worth for sure.

36272277.review:
Just started New Game+:

The game is overall, good. Combat is interesting and highly skill based, especially towards the end of the game; the monster damage ramps up slightly faster than the HP does, so theres a lot less room for bad technique. Power-leveling isn't really necessary if you don't avoid combat throughout the storyline, although I did feel the need to bump myself up 5 levels on the higher difficulty setting to buffer the sheer damage monsters do (1/3rd to 1/4th your player health per hit). 

Some things could use some work; many of the "item" buffs are lackluster and/or barely useful, and by far the most important stats and abilities are those that affect the time bar. Pretty much the only viable tactic is to focus on abilities that knock the opponent back down the time bar or outright remove them from combat, as at the higher levels the speeds are so fast it's very difficult to actually pull off an interrupt. CC and damage mititagion are absolutely vital to finishing the game.

The skill trees really don't do much to add spice to the character as far as playstyle; each character has a particular role in mind by the devs, and that's how they play regardless of how you build their skill tree. The Healer heals, the buffer buffs, the DPS does DPS, and the "Tank" doesn't have enough health to really tank, plus his "Taunt" ability doesn't block AoE attacks so really he's just DPS.

Luckily, the game allows party member swaps without penalty. For myself, it was really hard to break the concept that when it's a character's turn it's not just their turn; it's really ALL the character's turns. You can swap that character out for anyone who has the most effective ability to use for that specific turn. Once I started doing that though, the combat ran much smoother, although buffs are per-character and really don't jive with swapping out party members on-the-fly.

Comencemos con un resumen poco profesional: 
Encarnamos a Aurora, un niña que muere en nuestra dimensión pero resucita en otra... Específicamente en el reino de Lemura. El objetivo de nuestra pequeña protagonista es acabar con la reina de la oscuridad, que esta misma ha robado el sol, luna y estrellas. Aurora resuta ser una niña de luz, vaya que básicamente tenemos a la  candidata perfecta para darle en la madre (darle de hostias) a la oscuridad. Hablemos de su jugabilidad:
Child of light tiene una manera peculiar de jugabilidad... Un estilo de mundo abierto en 2d, bueno ni tanto, pero te recompensa por indagar por ahí, sin limitarte, pues desde que completas su introducción, puedes volar a todas partes y conseguir todas las cosas ocultas en ese lugar. Sus combates... Son excelentes, pues es por turnos, donde hay casteos y diferentes ataques con respectivas velocidades que bien puedes seleccionar una habilidad que tarda en ejecutarse o un ataque rápido para interrumpir el casteo de tus enemigos. El juego posee objetos típicos de estr estilo... Regeneradores de vida, maná y aumentos por turnos, y brillos... ¿Qué son esos brillos? Mejoras permamentes para tus personajes en sus estadisticas (vida, maná, defensa física, def. mágica, ataque fisico y mágico, velocidad en los turnos, probabilidad de critico y probabilidad de evasión. Tiene un sistema de niveles clasico... Árbol de habilidades que se dividen en tres ramas... Con la diferencia que si le das una buena jugada... Puedes tener todas las habilidades y pasivas. Tambien tiene un sistema de crafteo bastante simple, pero útil el Oculi, donde podemos hacer piedras y reafinarlas, para asignarlas ya sea como mejora ofensivas, defensivas, aumentos de estadisticas o algunas pasivas extras, pero no te emociones, pues solo pueden llevar tres cada personaje. Tiene la opción de NG+ al terminar el juego, por lo que conservas todas las estadísticas y objetos como brillos, piedras y pociones.

Hablemos de sus gráficas: 
Es un deleite visual... Te sentirás en un cuento, porque lo parece, es tan simple y hermoso, cada detalle y animación es perfecta. En serio, las animaciones están bien cuidadas y con detalles como si cruzas cerca de unos animales del fondo, reaccionan a tu presencia. Las animaciones de combate son excelentes y satisfactorias, el nivel de detalle es increible.
Pero esto es un arma de dos filos... Sí, ya te dije que todo está animado TODO... Eso consume recursos, por lo que el juego es disfritable a 60 fps, no menos, por lo que debes tener los requisitos recomendados, pues gráficamente el juego no se puede personalizar. 

Banda sonora y narración: 
Simplemente fantástico, supera expectativas y su banda sonora es simplemente perfecta. El juego la única voz que tiene es la de una mujer (en lo personal, prefiero la versión de consolas pues tiene el audio latino y los textos varían), que suena en contadas veces, el resto... Es un cuento que tienes que leer, si no aprecias el arte de las letras, de una vez descarta este juego se tu lista, debes tener aprecio por la poesia o literatura para que disfrutes el juego complemente, pero ojo jugarlo tampoco te hará un filósofo ni nada, solo te hará disfrutar mas del juego y ya.

Los pros ya te los he dicho en cada sección.

Los contras, pues aunque sea mi juego favorito, he encontrado todos sus fallos, creo.

Sin personalización gráfica.
A menos de 60 fps, el juego se descalibra con los sonidos y anotaciones.
Sin variedad en NG+.
Historia lineal y con un único final. (Te dará cuenta si solo te pasas el juego con aurora nada más)
DLC sin sentido. (Los tengo todos, y creo que los unicos que deberían estar a la venta son las skins, hay uno que agrega otro personaje, pero solo agega un poquito de lore)
El precio creo que no esta muy acorde ahora mismo, pues el juego ya salió hace años.

Contras personales:
No sacan la secuela!!! Por favor ubisoft, deja a los malditos rabbids y denme otro child of light!!!!

Recomendación de compra;
Si tenias en la vista otro juego compra ese juego. Si tienes apenas el dineronpara comprarlo, mejor espera a las rebajas. Si te sobra dinero, adelante, compralo cuando quieras, espero que lo disfrutes.

En conclusión... El juego es recomendado al cierto público que le guste leer. El juego es hermoso y deberían jugarlo todos, pero si eres alguien que prefiere pegar tiros o jugar juegos "Hardcore" (no mis niños, Dark souls, no entra en categoría hardcore) creo que no te gustará, a menos que tengas ganas de algo diferente a tu rutina de video jugador. 34603415.review:
Child of Light pairs gorgeous graphics with simple but effective music to create a storybook adventure that transports.

The animations and the settings are lovingly crafted. Exploring the landscape reminded me of the best illustrated storybooks I devoured as a small child. I wouldn't just read them again and again, but I'd also study the tiny details. In the visual story telling of Child of Light, background characters or far-off scenes, paint a picture, in water color style, of a larger world built on a mythic scale.

A nicely employed gimick turns your cursor into a firefly, an elemental spirit that you can use to interact with the environment remotely. The glowing blob acts as sort of a Swiss (well, Austrian, since that's where Aurora hails from) Army knife by lighting up dark areas, blinding opponents and even healing you and your companions.

As Aurora, you assemble a motley crew, some of which are more complex or interesting than the others. These characters often have exchanges that do not include Aurora and add more depth not just to the companions, but also to the greater story and their larger world. So much of Child of Light is about growing up, letting go of the past, good or bad, and letting it die so that the new can be born and the future embraced.

In addition to the various folk you encounter along the way, there are quite a few enemies to trounce. Strangely, your growing team of comrades, each with their own special skill trees, is always limited to one representative at a time on the battle field. There is facility for switching characters out, but I found it cumbersome and the fights generally easy enough not to bother with trying to stack together too many buffs or debuffs by swapping in different guys.

The combat, though adequate, is one of the two stumbles in Child of Light. By use of your cursor's blinding ability, it's possible to skip many of the fights; however, I wonder if the boss fights might be much more difficult without grinding out some experience. The fighting revolves around timing, how long a wind up takes and interrupting enemy attacks. It's not a bad system, but it feels conventional and focuses on violence as the only solution.

A game like Renowned Explorer's Society (as an example) employs a tactical rock/paper/scissors that allows for victory by charming or frightening/intimidating foes, as well as by beating the crap out of them, if you so choose. I think Child of Light could have benefited from a variety of minigames or some other challenge that would allow for alternate forms of advancing your character's growth and the story. It's not that I don't think that Aurora shouldn't fight; rather, limiting so much of her interaction outside of towns to fighting misses opportunities for more story telling. There are a variety of well drawn and interestingly animated bad guys, but only the bosses get any lines.

The other stumble, this one on the story-telling end, was in the choice to write the thing entirely in verse. Many reviews pan the game solely for the endless rhyme and the resulting awkward language. The game must have been a nightmare to translate. I often find even one character the speaks entirely in rhyme to be exhausting in most games or stories, so I worried that having the whole thing written that way would spoil the experience.

Since I expected nothing from the poetry, it surprised me by working, if only in fits and starts, here and there. Putting all the narrative, the dialog, and even the exclamations and interjections, into rhyme was an ambitious undertaking. I applaud UBIsoft the effort, but felt that the relentless poetry detracted, if only mildly, rather than added to my overall enjoyment of the game. YMMV

I was surprised by some genuinely touching moments in Child of Light, as well as some subtle visual story telling, backed by restrained, but sweetly, sadly haunting music. It used its fantastical characters as metaphors for facing the challenges that we all face in growing up and, eventually, becoming parent to the child. Poetry aside, Child of Light is a memorable, imaginative and satisfying fairy tale.

[h1]a sweet "gateway" rpg with a beautiful aesthetic.[/h1]

are you looking to get into rpg's, but all the rpg's terrify you because of their length and the ridiculous difficulty spike that goes along with managing stats, managing equipment, managing party members, doing the combat dance and generally worrying whether you're making all the right choices?

if this is the case, i'd like to introduce you to child of light.  child of light is a very simple "first" rpg that you can finish in 10-12 hours [my playtime is excessive, because i play games slowly and i tend to try and find ALL THE THINGS.]

[b]how it all works[/b]

child of light's framework is that of a storybook.  the minute you start the game, it recounts a simple narrative that takes place in a fantasy world that feels exactly like those bedtime stories you used to hear as a child.  "there was a princess" "she saw many strange things" - i'm sure you know exactly what i mean.

in this framework, you slowly collect party members that help you on your quest.  each party member has their own personality and their own strengths.  there are magic users, but each magic user does a different job.  there are physical characters, but each one tackles being physical in a different way.

combat is turn based and largely stress free, but you can only ever have two party members on screen at any time during combat, where the enemy almost always has three [this is somewhat mitigated by the easy drop-in/drop-out nature of the fights:  when it's your turn, you can easily swap to one of your other party members.  you can also flee at the drop of a hat if it's your turn with no serious repurcussions.]

there's no actual items to manage:  you get dust, which makes you better and jewels which you can forge into stat-boosting trinkets that do different things based on which equipment slot you put them into.  anything else you pick up is a part of the story.

in the same vein, conversations are scripted.  you don't need to worry about getting things wrong in conversation trees, because everything that is said is "the right thing at the right time to the right person."

with all this going for it, it's easy to make a case for this as your first rpg if you're even a little on the fence about the genre.  the visuals are charming, the music is beautiful [if repetitive - it's one of the very few downsides] and the story is sweet [though quite trope-y.  you'll spot many of the story beats coming a mile away.]

if you've never tried a rpg, i can heartily recommend this one.

[b]pros at a glance[/b]
[list]
[*]short, turn-based rpg with minimal "rpg headaches"
[*]beautiful visuals and simple, heartfelt story
[*]a great game for being introduced to rpg's
[*]a neat protgaonist and party members
[/list]

[b]cons at a glance[/b]
[*]the combat numbers can seem a little overwhelming [3 enemies, HUGE damage spikes]
[*]the music, while beautiful is repetitive
[*]those rhyming couplets [it's a great conceit stretched WAY too thin.]
[*]terrifically meh dlc.  buy the dresses and golem pack.  ignore the rest.

I find that there's a fine line to walk when it comes to a setting and story being airy and whimsical. Child of Light's dialog/story are presented as poetry, and it came off to me as very dismissive of anything being all that important. The game doesn't appear to be made for small children, but the dialog sounds to me like a bedtime story an adult would read to a small child in a soft tone, completely devoid of substance or sincerity; just trying to get the little rugrat to fall asleep rather than to actually entertain.

The music is charming, and the art style is rather pretty, which I feel are the game's biggest positives. The combat is alright, though it's clearly at a level of difficulty higher than what a small child could handle, so this further evidences that the story was meant for more mature people capable of winning its battles.

Unfortunately, the whimsy of its story completely obliterated all sense of urgency or interest I had in the game. 33781455.review:
Child of Light is without a doubt one of the games I've most enjoyed playing in a long time. Although this game is already 3 years old, I still very much have wanted to make a review of this game. Also, English is not my main language, so sorry if there is a grammar mistake or something sounds weirdly redacted.

Personally, I liked everything from this game, though I know there are some aspects that might not be as liked by others, and it is completely understandable. Let's get into that.

- The story: It's not the most outstanding aspect of the game, but it's not something terrible that brings the whole game down either. It's very confusing if you do not pay attention to the dialogue of the characters, and that isn't always too easy since the narration in this game is always "poetic", which isn't bad but can really get unclear or confusing. It's the way that everything is written in a verse that makes the story interesting, because it somehow makes it pleasant to read or listen to. If you have trouble understanding poetic elements such as metaphors, then I highly suggest paying attention to the dialogue if you don't want a confusing ending.

- The characters: The character design is one outstanding element in this game, they really reflect the fantasy theme the game features, and each one of them have their very own interesting backstory. The characters is one thing that you'll remember after playing the game.

- The gameplay: It is fairly balanced, there's nothing that will be incredibly overpowered, and if there is it's because you're probably not preparing yourself enough. This is not simply a turn-based game, there is also a feature in the combat system which is a meter that indicates the order in which all entities in a battle will perform an action in every turn, which is a really cool mechanic in the game. The combat system allows you to use 2 characters at the same time (of course you can also swap them out with others). It might sound weird, but if the 2 characters that are currently in the field are dead it counts as game over, even if you still have other alive members in your party. This is actually pretty great because it encourages you to play strategically and swap out between characters when you need to.

- Role distribution: Each playable character is highly different from one another. You have your all-round class whose stats vary depending on how you build their skill tree; you have a mage that excels in magic damage and magic resistance who also has access to elemental attacks; you have several supportive roles, but each one of them offers different supportive abilities (heals, revives and status condition defense / provides buffs to allies / provides debuffs to enemies); you have your high-reward high-risk class who can dish out a lot of damage, but is also pretty squishy, its higher than average crit chance and dodge chance makes up for that; and finally you have your tank class with considerably more health who is all about taking the hits for the team.
What does this all mean? You're never gonna feel a character exactly the same as other, which means they have good gameplay design.

- Other features: This game has something called Occuli, which basically are fragments you can give to your characters to boost a specific stat or add a little tweak to their resistances and attacks. I like and dislike this feature at the same time. The game hardly gives any explanation on to how they work or what even they are for. You constantly rely on them, which isn't necessarily bad but I can understand why some people might hate that.  

- The music: Last but not least, the music. If there is anything you slightly didn't like from the game, the music will surely make up for it. I found myself repeteadly listening to the soundtrack after finishing the game. They fit the scenes and ambients in which they play.

Do I highly suggest this game? Absolutely. If you like turn-based RPGs with interesting characters, music and combat mechanics, then this game will not let you down. And if you're up for a bigger challenge, you can try out the expert mode unlocked after finishing a normal playthrough.

¡Una obra de arte, en forma de RPG!
Child of Light nos narra a modo de poema un cuento ambientado a finales del siglo XIX donde la protagonista, Aurora, es hija de los Duques de Austria; y cuya madre falleció en misteriosas circunstancias. 

En nuestro periplo por librar a nuestro reino: Lemuria, del yugo de Umbra, una bruja que ha robado el sol, la luna y las estrellas; surcaremos el cielo, nos adentraremos en las profundidades de la tierra y nos sumergiremos en los oceanos. En cada ciudad y paraje que visitemos, conoceremos a las diferentes criaturas que habitan este mundo de cuento, algunas de las cuales, se unirán de nuestro lado al sentir que sus desgraciadas vidas no tienen sentido si la situación del reino continua así.

Una aventura propia de un cuento de hadas, con giros argumentales que sorprenden al jugador. Un cuento escrito y narrado magistralmente en verso, convirtiendo al título en poesía viva que, junto al apartado gráfico, lo definen como una obra de arte hecha juego.

El juego no sólo rompe con lo tradicional con su original narrativa, sino que en el apartado gráfico da un giro de 180º al género. El apartado visual destaca por su belleza. Estamos ante un título de scroll lateral en 2D, donde lo único que posee algún polígono es el personaje de Aurora. El resto del entorno y personajes son fantásticas y preciosas ilustraciones hechas a acuarela, de las cuales casi se pueden percibir las pinceladas. Gráficos vivos y altamente detallados convierten a Child of Light en un cuadro viviente, con un diseño hermoso de personajes y de entornos.

Quizá Child of Light no sea el mejor RPG por turnos de los últimos tiempos, pero sí uno muy a tener en cuenta tanto por su apartado visual, su narrativa y su hermoso apartado sonoro. Graficamente sublime, parece que un cuadro cobra vida ante nuestros ojos tanto por la apariencia como por el nivel de detalle, especialmente de los escenarios. La implementacion de nuestro compañero -y guía- Ignículus dentro de las batallas le dan un toque fresco y original, convirtiendo cada uno de los combates en una prueba de velocidad en nuestro planteamiento de la batalla según los diferentes contratiempos que puden surgir de la misma.

While this was not only very disappointing from a story perspective, as I really liked her character, it was [i]completely unacceptable[/i] from a gameplay standpoint. There are a lot of things going on with this game, so I guess I'll just break it into parts. I'll start with the gameplay:

This game has a two-dimensional overworld. Enemies are shown on the overworld, and can be engaged or avoided. Combat takes place in a separate battle screen. From a gameplay perspective, the combat system is probably the most interesting and novel thing about the game. There are a number of options for slowing enemies down, and striking a foe at the right time can "interrupt" them. Of course they can also interrupt you if you aren't careful. This can often make combat feel like you are juggling enemies, which I liked.

On to story and writing: The story is very much a straight-up fairy tale about a princess coming of age and saving her kingdom. The characters are fairly colorful and varied. Also, all dialogue is written in rhyme, which could be a positive or a negative. I personally found it endearing, but I can see how others could find it maddening. Overall, it's a fairly light-hearted adventure.

I liked the visuals too. They were fairly simple, and high-contrast, which I thought worked well with the story.

30827544.review:
A new take on the Sleeping Beauty story you didn't realize you needed.




The artwork is simple yet phenomenal. The dialogue is written in rhymes, giving the game a much more whimsical and light mood in contrast to the more 'depressing' themes in the game

The OST - written partly by Coeur de Pirate - follows the story extremely well and adds much ambiance to the various settings of Lemuria. If there were an option to buy this alongside the game, I 100% would

As for the combat, the game 'forces' you to think on your feet. Like many turn--based RPGs, each character takes their turn in combat with the catch being that there's a 'time bar' on which ALL characters (including enemies) move along. Most of the bar is used for initial move casting where allies and enemies 'prepare' to cast spells and use abilities. The last end of the bar is the 'casting' phase and is crucial: This is where you choose your spell/attack/defense, with some things having a longer cast time than others. If a character takes damage while casting, they are interrupted and sent back to the prepare phase. There is much more to the combat, but I'll let those of you that do choose to purchase it experience it yourselves




TL;DR
10/10 would rhyme again
